#### $1,000,000,000

 Rocket Software, Inc.

#####      % Senior Secured Notes due 2028

The Offering:

- Rocket Software, Inc., a Delaware corporation (the “Issuer”), is offering $1,000,000,000 aggregate principal amount of     % senior secured notes due 2028 (the “notes”). The notes are
being issued in connection with our proposed acquisition (the “AMC Acquisition”) of the Application Modernization and Connectivity business (the “AMC business”) of Open Text
Corporation (“OpenText”).

- Use of Proceeds: We intend to use the net proceeds from the offering of the notes, together with borrowings under our Incremental First Lien Term Loan Facilities (as defined herein), proceeds
from the Equity Contribution (as defined herein) and cash on hand, to (i) finance and consummate the AMC Acquisition and (ii) pay transaction expenses and fees in connection with the
foregoing. See “Use of Proceeds.”

- Escrow: This offering may be consummated prior to the consummation of the AMC Acquisition. If the issue date of the notes occurs prior to the date that the AMC Acquisition is consummated
(the “Acquisition Date”), the Issuer will execute and deliver the Escrow Agreement (as defined herein) on the issue date of the notes and will deposit, or cause to be deposited, an amount
equal to the gross proceeds from the offering of the notes into an escrow account (the “Escrow Account” and the funds deposited therein, the “Escrowed Property”) for the benefit of the
holders of the notes pending the consummation of the AMC Acquisition. The release of Escrowed Property to the Issuer to consummate the AMC Acquisition will be subject to the satisfaction
of certain conditions (the “Escrow Release Conditions”), including the closing of the AMC Acquisition substantially concurrently with or promptly following the release of the Escrowed
Property. The consummation of the AMC Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including regulatory conditions. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the regulatory
conditions in the Acquisition Agreement (as defined herein) have been satisfied. If (i) the closing of the AMC Acquisition has not occurred on or prior to July 5, 2024, (such date, the “Outside
Date”), (ii) we notify the Trustee in writing prior to the Outside Date that we will not pursue the consummation of the AMC Acquisition or (iii) the Acquisition Agreement has been terminated
prior to the Outside Date without the consummation of the AMC Acquisition, we will be required to redeem all of the outstanding notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the outstanding
principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, from and including the issue date of the notes, or the most recent date to which interest has been paid on the notes, whichever
is later, to, but not including, the special mandatory redemption date. The Escrow Account will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest owing to holders of the notes, which
is included in the special mandatory redemption price. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

The Senior Notes:

- Maturity: The notes will mature on November 28, 2028.

- Interest: The notes will bear interest at a rate of      % per annum. Interest on the notes will accrue from     , 2024 and will be payable semi-annually, in cash in arrears, on      and
of each year, commencing     , 2024.

- Guarantees: If the offering of the notes is consummated prior to the Acquisition Date, then prior to the Acquisition Date and pending the release of the Escrowed Property, if applicable, the
notes will not be guaranteed. From and after the Acquisition Date and following the release of the Escrowed Property, if applicable, the notes will be jointly and severally, irrevocably, fully
and unconditionally guaranteed on a senior secured basis by each of the Issuer’s then current and future (i) wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries and (ii) wholly-owned restricted
subsidiaries organized under the laws of England or Wales that guarantee or will guarantee the Senior Secured Credit Facilities (as defined herein) (collectively, the “Guarantors”).

- Security: If the offering of the notes is consummated prior to the Acquisition Date, then prior to the Acquisition Date and pending the release of the Escrowed Property, if applicable, the notes
will be secured only by a first priority security interest in the Escrow Account and Escrowed Property. From and after the Acquisition Date and following the release of the Escrowed Property,
if applicable, the notes and related guarantees will be secured by a first-priority lien, subject to permitted liens, on all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ existing and future assets that secure
the Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

- Ranking: From and after the Acquisition Date and following the release of the Escrowed Property, if applicable, the notes and the related guarantees will be the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’
senior secured obligations and will be secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. The notes and the related guarantees will be effectively senior in right of payment
to all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ existing and future junior lien and unsecured senior debt, including the Existing Notes (as defined below), to the extent of the value of the collateral
securing the notes, and equal in right of payment to any indebtedness secured on an equal-priority basis, including the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. The notes will rank equally in right of
payment with any of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ obligations under any existing and future senior indebtedness and other obligations that are not, by their terms expressly subordinated in
right of payment to the notes, including the Existing Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, without giving effect to collateral arrangements. The notes will rank senior in right of
payment to any of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ existing and future subordinated indebtedness, and will be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness and other
liabilities of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the notes.

- Optional Redemption and Repurchase: We may redeem some or all of the notes at any time prior to    , 2025 at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes redeemed, plus
accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus a “make-whole” premium and, at any time on or after    , 2025, at the redemption prices specified under
“Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.” In addition, at any time prior to     , 2025, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes may be redeemed with the net proceeds
of certain equity offerings, at the redemption price specified under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.” In addition, until     , 2025, we may redeem up to 10% of the original
aggregate principal amount of the notes during each twelve-month period commencing from the issue date of the notes at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. If we experience certain change of control triggering events, holders of the notes will have the right to require us to
repurchase the notes under the terms set forth herein. See “Description of Notes—Change of Control.”

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION**

In this offering memorandum, we present certain historical financial data of the Issuer and the AMC business. This
offering memorandum contains the audited consolidated financial statements of the Issuer for the years ended
December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021. These financial statements were prepared in accordance with generally accepted
accounting principles in the United States (“GAAP”).

This offering memorandum also contains the audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business.
The AMC business includes historically a product group of Micro Focus International Limited (“Micro Focus”) and,
beginning February 1, 2023, the OpenText Connectivity business (“OT Connectivity”), a product group of OpenText.
OpenText acquired all of the issued and to be issued share capital of Micro Focus on January 31, 2023 (the “MF
Acquisition”). The AMC business has historically operated as part of Micro Focus or, following acquisition thereof,
OpenText and not as a standalone company. The audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business
included elsewhere in this offering memorandum are presented on a “carve-out” basis from (i) Micro Focus’s
accounting records for the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023 and (ii) OpenText’s accounting records
for the period from and after February 1, 2023, using the historical results of operations, cash flows, assets and
liabilities of the AMC business. For the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023, the audited combined
carveout financial statements of the AMC business exclude OT Connectivity. The audited combined carveout financial
statements of the AMC business include allocations of corporate expenses and shared expenses from Micro Focus for
the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023 (prior to the MF Acquisition) and OpenText for the period from
and after February 1, 2023 (following the MF Acquisition). These allocations reflect significant assumptions and the
combined financial statements may not fully reflect what the AMC business’s financial position, results of operations
or cash flows would have been had it been a standalone company during the periods presented. As a result, the audited
combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business included elsewhere in this offering memorandum are
not necessarily indicative of the AMC business’s future results of operations, financial position or cash flows. The
audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business were prepared in accordance with GAAP.

Except as expressly noted, OpenText has not prepared or reviewed any information about the AMC business or the
combined business for this offering memorandum or confirmed the accuracy of the information included in this
offering memorandum. Additionally, the audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business that
are included in this offering memorandum have not been separately filed with, or furnished to, the SEC by OpenText.

**NON-GAAP FINANCIAL MEASURES**

We have included certain financial measures that are not based on GAAP in this offering memorandum, including
Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue, Non-GAAP Cost of Revenue, Non-GAAP Gross Profit, EBITDA, Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA, Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA Margin, Free Cash Flow
and Free Cash Flow Conversion with respect to the Issuer and the AMC business, as applicable (collectively, the
“Non-GAAP Metrics”). We believe that these measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating


-----

performance from period to period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core
business. We believe that they provide investors with a useful tool for assessing the comparability between periods of
our ability to generate cash from operations sufficient to pay taxes, to service debt and to undertake capital
expenditures. We use these measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to
that of our competitors.

Certain of our Non-GAAP Metrics have been calculated utilizing accounting principles not consistent with GAAP,
including recognizing revenue on an Annual Recurring Revenue (“ARR”) basis rather than in accordance with
Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Update No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (“ASC
606”). A primary difference between ARR and ASC 606 is the accounting for license revenue in our subscription or
term license arrangements, which is annualized and recognized over the contract term under our ARR method, while
recognized at a point in time, generally at the inception of the contract term, under ASC 606.

Our use of the Non-GAAP Metrics varies from others in our industry. Our Non-GAAP Metrics should not be
considered as alternatives to net income (loss), revenue or other measures of performance derived in accordance with
GAAP as measures of operating performance or operating cash flows or as measures of liquidity.

Our Non-GAAP Metrics have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation
or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under GAAP. Some of these limitations are:

    - such measures do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

    - such measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

    - such measures do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest payments, on our debts;

    - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized
will often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for
such replacements;

    - non-cash compensation, including in connection with certain acquisitions, is and will remain an element
of our overall long-term incentive compensation package, although we exclude it as an expense when
evaluating our ongoing operating performance for a particular period;

    - such measures do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not
to be indicative of our ongoing operations;

    - such measures reflect estimated cost savings and synergies that may not be achieved; and

    - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

In this offering memorandum, we disclose the Non-GAAP Metrics with respect to the Issuer and the AMC business
on a standalone and pro forma basis, as applicable. Some of the Non-GAAP Metrics with respect to the AMC business
were prepared by us based on certain financial information obtained through our financial diligence process. The
methodology for preparing such financial information is different than the methodology used by OpenText to prepare
the audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business (including with respect to the allocation of
shared costs) and such Non-GAAP Metrics should therefore not be viewed as substitutes for the AMC business’s
results as reported under GAAP. OpenText neither prepared nor reviewed these Non-GAAP Metrics, and OpenText
does not utilize any such Non-GAAP Metrics in its own reporting with respect to the AMC business. We have not yet
closed the AMC Acquisition, and the Non-GAAP Metrics with respect to the AMC business are therefore subject to
certain adjustments and changes after we close the AMC Acquisition and integrate the AMC business into our own
business.


-----

For a more detailed discussion and reconciliations of our Non-GAAP Metrics to their most directly comparable GAAP
measures, see “Summary––Summary Historical and Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information.”

The financial information included in this offering memorandum is not intended to comply with the requirements of

**Our Company**

Rocket is a leading global enterprise software provider with a broad portfolio of products that help corporations,
government agencies, and other organizations run their mission-critical IT operations. We enable small and large
enterprises in many industries to maximize their data, systems and infrastructure to deliver critical services that power
our modern world. Our software runs, optimizes and protects our customers’ applications, servers and databases, and
integrates these core platforms with the rest of the enterprise, while providing a full-stack of modernization solutions.
Our products enable customers to carry out their most mission-critical business functions, such as processing payment
transactions at global financial institutions and maintaining healthcare records at hospitals and insurance companies.

Since our founding over 30 years ago, we have cultivated a customer-centric culture with strategic investments in
research and development (“R&D”) that provide a wide range of solutions to meet customers’ evolving needs. We
have evolved from solely maintaining legacy infrastructure to facilitating modernization journeys to connect
mainframe to the hybrid cloud environment. We have accomplished this evolution through substantial R&D efforts,
highlighted by over $500 million in investments into R&D since 2020, as well as multiple acquisitions that have
expanded our modernization offering.

Given our focus on supporting our customers’ mission-critical business functions, our products address deeply
embedded technologies that sit at the core of enterprise IT infrastructure. These systems have evolved over multiple
decades and, particularly for our largest customers, represent billions of dollars of cumulative custom application
development and IT infrastructure investment. As enterprises look to the future, hybrid remains vital to enabling the
deployment of cloud environments as it incorporates client server computing, cloud-based platforms, and modern
connectivity and portability.

We seek to enable our customers to experience the best of both the cloud and the mainframe, putting relevant
workloads in the cloud while leveraging the mainframe for its best features – security, reliability, and governance.
Our strategy is to modernize without disruption, meeting customers where they are in their modernization journey. By
utilizing our product portfolio, customers can modernize effectively, even incrementally, integrating new technologies
while preserving and leveraging the robust foundation already in place for a seamless technological evolution. We
believe this approach dramatically lowers risk and improves success rates of IT system modernization projects.

As the pace of digital transformation continues to accelerate, we believe our customers will increasingly look to us to
extract greater value from existing IT systems and applications through innovation, integration, optimization and
modernization.

Today, Rocket is organized into three main business units focused on Infrastructure Modernization, Data
Modernization and Application Modernization. While each business unit has its own technical requirements and
products, we go to market using a holistic approach to solving our customers’ problems, utilizing solutions across our
business units to help drive operating efficiencies among overlapping buying centers to best position us to drive future
growth. These business units are as follows:

_Infrastructure Modernization: Our Infrastructure Modernization business unit represents approximately_
55% of our standalone revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. It comprises software solutions built
for integrating and optimizing mainframe workloads, mitigating security and compliance risks and
optimizing storage. Organizations can leverage our range of solutions to support mainframe security and


-----

compliance in the face of new threats and deliver optimized mainframe performance management and
interoperability. The mainframe continues to be an integral part of modern-day IT infrastructure and
provides a reliable architecture for high-volume data processing and transactions. Mainframes provide a
level of five 9s of availability (99.999%), which is several orders of magnitude higher than alternative
distributed servers, making mainframes the optimal platform for mission-critical processes. Additionally,
mainframes are uniquely engineered to process millions of input and output calculations per second, which
is a key difference from distributed servers that are designed to be more general purpose, limiting their
ability to perform a specialized task extremely well. Consequently, mainframes provide a range of
advantages over distributed systems that are likely to persist, and we believe organizations in regulated and
data intensive industries will continue to rely on mainframe systems to process high-volume, missioncritical activity at the core of their IT infrastructures.

_Data Modernization: Our Data Modernization business unit represents approximately 18% of our_
standalone revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. It provides software solutions to connect
mission-critical data residing on the mainframe and distributed systems to advanced applications and
compute workloads running on private and public cloud environments. As organizations increasingly adopt
a hybrid cloud infrastructure approach to operations, effectively navigating the complexities of data
governance and compliance while maximizing data utilization is critical. Our solutions address this
challenge by eliminating data siloes to enhance decision-making and customer experience while maintaining
strong data governance, security, scalability and dynamic availability. For example, one of our key products,
Mobius, enables customers to integrate seamlessly with third-party repositories, facilitating secure and
efficient data movement between modern and legacy systems. Our track record of successfully integrating
acquisitions within this business unit highlights our commitment to providing an end-to-end offering that
reframes customer engagement strategies and paves the way for future growth.

_Application Modernization: Our Application Modernization business unit represents the remaining 27% of_
our standalone revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. It is comprised of a portfolio of solutions
aimed at improving application responsiveness and engagement across hybrid environments by creating
modern workflows for legacy applications. While Application Modernization covers both distributed offmainframe platforms and mainframe environments, many of the most important back-end applications for
large enterprises still reside on the mainframe and have yet to be modernized. With key offerings including
database management, DevOps, and low-code application development platforms, we enable organizations
to efficiently deliver reliable, scalable and secure applications to support their core business needs. One of
our key innovations has been to enable enterprise adoption of unified DevOps across mainframe and hybrid
cloud architectures, which enables teams to deploy modern development practices even for legacy systems.

Across these three business units, we serve over 12,500 end-user customers, pro forma for the AMC Acquisition. Our
customer base spans every major industry vertical and includes some of the largest companies in the world, including
43 of the Fortune 50, as of 2023 (excluding the impact of the AMC Acquisition). Our customer base is highly
diversified with the top ten Rocket-led customers representing just 14% of revenue in the year ended December 31,
2023 (excluding the impact of the AMC Acquisition).

In addition to these deeply embedded and long-term customer relationships, we have also cultivated a number of
partnerships that are critical to our business. Our largest partnership is with IBM. We generate approximately 23% of
our revenue through IBM-led sales. Through a series of organic R&D investments, acquisitions, joint development
efforts and a strong go-to-market (“GTM”) partnership, we have become one of IBM’s most trusted software partners.
This partnership has evolved over 30 years and is driven primarily by our expertise in mainframe and mid-range
servers of which IBM is a major manufacturer. Our software enhances and creates efficiencies for IBM’s customers
and extends the life of IBM’s core platforms. In partnership with IBM, we develop and support core software offerings
in their portfolio, freeing IBM to redirect their R&D spend to other areas. As part of our partnership with IBM,
numerous Rocket products are re-branded as IBM products and sold through their global salesforce.

While we are committed to remaining a high-quality business partner to IBM and extending the lifetime value of core
IBM-led products, we are working to increase the share of Rocket-led sales to further diversify our revenue. Our
Rocket-led GTM strategy, whether executed directly or through our channel partners, allows us to provide best-in

-----

class support to our customers in managing their mainframe and modernization journey, particularly as they move
towards a hybrid cloud environment.

We are headquartered in Waltham, Massachusetts and maintain a large global footprint with significant operations in
North America, the United Kingdom, Europe, Asia and Australia. As of December 31, 2023 we had 2,200 employees
(excluding the impact of the AMC Acquisition) worldwide with a presence in 13 global offices. Following the AMC
Acquisition, we expect to have approximately 3,000 Rocketeers and 20 global offices. This worldwide coverage
provides us with access to economies of scale, lower cost offshore operations, high-growth emerging markets and
global support for our increasingly global customer base.

**Acquisition of Application Modernization and Connectivity**

On November 28, 2023, we entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the AMC business of OpenText, which
includes historically a product group of Micro Focus and, beginning February 1, 2023, the OT Connectivity business,
a product group of OpenText, for an all-cash purchase price of $2.275 billion, before taxes, fees and other adjustments.
For more information, see “––The AMC Acquisition.”

The AMC business has been a leader in application modernization for many years with a focus on mainframe
replatforming solutions that help with the migration and operation of mainframe workloads to distributed and cloud
environments. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the AMC business generated Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue
of $504 million and Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA of $307 million. AMC Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue is
comprised of (x) for the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately $355 million of ARR, $108 million of
perpetual license revenue and $13 million of professional service revenue, and (y) for the year ended December 31,
2023, approximately $364 million of ARR, $121 million of perpetual license revenue and $20 million of professional
services revenue. The AMC business operates within five portfolio segments that form a comprehensive suite for
mainframe application development, maintenance and modernization:

_Enterprise Suite: The AMC business’s Enterprise Suite business unit represents approximately 18% of its_
revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. This solution is the AMC business’s fastest growing product
line, providing end-to-end mainframe workload migration tools including migration analysis, test and
deployment tools and an enterprise server that emulates the mainframe environment in the cloud. The
Enterprise Suite helps organizations move mainframe workloads to run on distributed environments with a
significantly lower degree of code change relative to other complex migration options like refactoring.
Within the Enterprise Suite, four core tools address different stages of workload migration and application
development. The Analyzer, Developer and Enterprise Test Server are focused on delivering diagnostic
tools, modern Integrated Development Environments (“IDE”) and virtual test environments. The Enterprise
Server provides a multi-platform production environment to replatform IBM z/OS applications. The revenue
derived from Enterprise Server is highly recurring in nature and allows for an emulated mainframe on cloud
environments with the ability to run mission-critical applications.

_COBOL: The AMC business’s Common Business Oriented Language (“COBOL”) business unit represents_
approximately 36% of its revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. This solution enables
organizations to develop, maintain and deploy COBOL based applications across the enterprise using
modern DevOps tools and platforms. COBOL is a legacy programming language that is integral to the
majority of mission-critical applications. As most developers lack experience working in COBOL, a modern
set of DevOps tools enables enterprises to modernize and update their most important applications. The
AMC business’s tools provide an IDE for analyzing and editing COBOL in applications primarily offmainframe, providing developers with visualizations and coding environments similar to modern IDEs. As
one indicator of the AMC business’s market position, the AMC business is the only official COBOL
compiler available on Cloud Service Providers’ (“CSPs”) marketplaces.

_Host Connectivity: The AMC business’s Host Connectivity business unit represents approximately 32% of_
its revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. This solution includes mainframe terminal emulators and
plugins for application access, process automation and security solutions. Customer use cases include
providing flexible access to mission-critical applications running on mainframe environments via modern,
distributed systems (desktop, web and mobile) in a secure and compliant manner (i.e. multi factor


-----

authentication). The AMC business’s Host Connectivity tools provide a broad number of options that allow
for significant customization to deliver strong, auditable and compliant security that meets organizations’
requirements.

_Mainframe Application Development Life Cycle Management (“ADLM”): The AMC business’s Mainframe_
ADLM business unit represents approximately 11% of its revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023.
This solution provides mainframe source code change, configuration and management enabling
organizations to modernize and integrate mainframes across new technologies and platforms. This results
in shorter app delivery cycles, stronger security and increased productivity. Customer use cases include
version control functionality to track changes made to source code (i.e. ChangeMan ZMF), change
management workflow, release management and automation, automated testing, auditing and reporting.

_CORBA: The AMC business’s Common Object Request Broker Architecture (“CORBA”) business unit_
represents approximately 3% of its revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. This solution provides
middleware for communication across distributed applications. CORBA add-on solutions enable any
CORBA application to take advantage of new deployment models, including cloud, containers and virtual
environments or to extend and re-use existing CORBA resources without prior knowledge of CORBA
technology. These solutions are used in telecommunications for managing network elements and the
integration of different vendor equipment, in military and defense for building command and control
systems and in finance for trading and risk management systems.

The AMC Acquisition represents a highly complementary addition to our product portfolio, with the AMC business
expected to further build out a more diverse modernization portfolio that aligns with customer demands and allows us
to meet our customers wherever they are on their modernization journey. The AMC Acquisition is expected to achieve

  - Expanding the product portfolio with a stronger, more comprehensive modernization offering that is able to
meet customers at any stage of their IT modernization journey, whether modernizing in place, migrating

  - Providing a full-stack of products and solutions to enable end-to-end modernization without the disruption
of existing workflows and allow customers to derive value from their decades of investment in core
applications;

  - Expanding customer reach through deeper and broader customer engagement across Fortune 2000 accounts
for greater retention and cross-selling. A more comprehensive and complete offering solidifies Rocket as the
strategic partner of choice to address customer needs, tapping into developer-led decisions and guiding
customers through their modernization journey over time, ultimately expanding Rocket’s relevance;

  - Tapping into CSP budget pools through the AMC business’s replatforming capabilities, augmenting our
existing hybrid cloud solutions suite and expanding our footprint with CSPs including Google Cloud
Platform, Amazon Web Services, and Microsoft Azure as preferred replatforming partners;

  - Expanding our global reach, with a stronger presence in Europe, Middle East and Africa (“EMEA”), Asia
Pacific, and Latin American channels, thus diversifying our revenue sources and redistributing geographic
concentrations; and

  - Combining R&D engines to drive increased innovation, better modernization capabilities and more elegant
solutions to further accelerate a shifty to hybrid cloud technology. The AMC business’s additional resources
for innovation will foster continuous R&D innovation through the application of emerging technologies like
generative artificial intelligence.

Acquiring the AMC business’s replatforming capabilities and strong relationships with CSPs, including Google Cloud
Platform, Amazon Web Services, and Microsoft Azure, is expected to enable us to tap into new budget pools and
augment our existing hybrid cloud solutions suite. Rocket has broken down the boundaries of on-premises and cloud


-----

computing so that businesses can connect IT systems and modern applications. The seamless data flow, data
integration and continuous enhancements create benefits like streamlined processes, improved efficiencies, and better
return on investment so that customers can be more dynamic, secure, and agile in the face of an increasingly complex
IT and business environment. Access to the AMC business’s additional software developers will drive increased

**Our GTM Strategy**

Our marketing and GTM strategies are driven, first and foremost, to deliver the right solutions to customers, regardless
of channel. To that end, our sales and marketing efforts are bifurcated between our Rocket-led products and our IBMled products, each of which have their own strategies.

Our Rocket-led products are sold through two primary avenues: (1) direct to customer through our centralized
customer success, support and delivery teams and (2) channel partners.

  - Our direct sales force and marketing investment, which is focused on Rocket-led solutions, is shifting the
dialogue from mainframe buying centers to a Chief Information Officer (“CIO”) and Chief Product Officer
(“CPO”) strategy covering the expanse of Rocket use cases. We rely on marketing to drive brand awareness,
generate leads across our growth product areas and support subscription and maintenance renewals by
reinforcing the value delivered by our new releases and product innovation. Through our 30-year operating
history and over 50 acquisitions, we have a strong base of customers that we continually look to serve with
our growing portfolio of solutions. Our sales force targets both existing customers and new logo opportunities
and is comprised of a global set of enterprise sales professionals focused on account relationships. Our
enterprise sales professionals are product specialists who focus on selling our solutions with our solutions
engineers providing technical guidance to customers throughout the sales process. This team handles new
sales as well as up-sells and cross-sells within existing accounts, further driving revenue expansion. Renewals
of existing maintenance contracts and subscriptions are handled by our centralized renewal team, who have
helped to drive our consistently high renewal rates.

  - In addition to our direct sales force, our Rocket-led sales organization also leads our strategic alliances. Our
10 strategic channel partner relationships consist of resellers, distributors and systems integrators who embed
our solutions in other software applications and help to deliver new solutions to market. Our strong
relationships with Independent Software Vendors (“ISVs”) and Managed Service Providers (“MSPs”) enable
us to better reach both current and potential customers, and these strong MSP relationships also support
customers using MSPs to manage their mainframe.

For our IBM-led products, we have a dedicated sales enablement team across the IBM Original Equipment
Manufacturer (“OEM”) product segments, all backed by a 30-year longstanding partnership driving us and IBM to
partner on opportunities and deployments. These joint Rocket-IBM sales and marketing initiatives allow us to drive
demand, refine messaging, enable sales and strengthen win rates for our IBM-led products, which continue to have
strong retention rates supported by the strength of our partnership with IBM. In addition to benefits that we realize
from the partnership, IBM also leverages us to support the broader mainframe industry and expand value delivered
from incumbent involvement.

Ultimately, our powerful GTM strategy is bolstered by a centralized customer success and support effort with global
coverage, a dedicated team focused on renewals and driving upsell and cross-sell opportunities across the installed
base, numerous strategic alliances that help market and distribute our solutions and a robust partnership with IBM.
The combination of these factors forms our strong customer success engine and continues to help us drive strong
retention rates.

We have further built our business to serve the expanding needs of our customers and address growing budget pools
that are focused on digital transformation. We’ve transitioned from a focus on providing solutions to the head of
infrastructure to addressing a head of applications or a Chief Data Officer who is focused on driving revenue
generation of their business. Whether it is the CIO or the Chief Data Officer, we have solutions that address their


-----

mission-critical challenges and our GTM approach ensures that we serve the different needs of our expanded buyer
set. The combined forces of Rocket and the AMC business are expected to create a broader product offering that
serves the entire modernization continuum, all in a single partner.

As one example of how the AMC Acquisition will help broaden our product offering and modernization capabilities,
we expect the AMC business to provide us with additional GTM channels to tap into CSP budget pools given the
AMC business’s strength in replatforming capabilities and strong relationships with CSPs. We believe this will further
elevate Rocket’s status with MSPs, CSPs and other key ecosystem participants, further strengthening and
differentiating our GTM strategy.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

_Deep and Embedded Portfolio of Solutions Meets Customer Needs Across Environments_

Since our founding, we have focused strategically on innovation to develop and enhance our software solutions to
consistently meet our customers’ evolving needs. Our portfolio of solutions represents a full-stack of purpose-built
products tailored to various end markets. Within each of these environments, we address customer pain points at every
layer of their IT system. This ranges from the core IT infrastructure (i.e. software tooling for the mainframe itself or
an embedded database) to newly developed applications that are open source in nature and run in the cloud but need
to integrate with the more traditional components of a customer’s IT system. In delivering this comprehensive portfolio
of products, we focus on opportunities categorized within our three synergistic business lines: Infrastructure
Modernization, Data Modernization and Application Modernization. We expect the AMC Acquisition to bring a suite
of tools with a focus on mainframe modernization and replatforming that help with the migration of critical mainframe
workloads to distributed and cloud environments. The AMC Acquisition is expected to broaden our existing product
portfolio with complementary modernization solutions and an increased focus on enabling migration to the cloud.

Illustrative use cases that enable customers throughout their modernization journey include but are not limited to:

  - Creating modern platforms and tools that are faster, cheaper and lower risk than replacing incumbent systems
to modernize;

  - Providing a toolset for mainframe replatforming and management of critical mainframe migration workloads;

  - Providing the tools for modern, compliant, and agile developer experiences;

  - Managing and operating core IT infrastructure more efficiently without forcing disruptive re-platforming;

  - Connecting legacy systems with cloud infrastructure; and

  - Managing accelerating data growth and provide real-time access for AI, machine learning (“ML”), data and
analytics.

**Our Strategy**

_Embrace Hybrid Cloud to Enable Enterprises to Unlock New Capabilities and Growth Opportunities and_
_Simultaneously Optimize Mission-Critical Systems_

Through our strategy of enabling enterprises to embrace and innovate with hybrid cloud, companies can deploy,
execute and manage workloads, applications and data agnostic of their chosen infrastructure in a seamless and
transparent manner from mainframe to cloud. This approach allows enterprises to not only maximize the full potential
and value of their data stored on mainframe, but also leverage that data to drive decisions and insights from cloudnative capabilities, including AI, ML and advanced analytics. One of our key innovations has been to enable enterprise
adoption of unified DevOps across mainframe and hybrid cloud architectures, which enables teams to deploy modern
development practices even for legacy systems and which we expect the AMC Acquisition to further enhance. This
will empower our customers as they pursue their modernization journeys, and we are right there with them. Ultimately,
this narrative aligns the technology investments made by enterprises with their key business outcomes, providing
customers with a complete lifecycle of solutions and letting them focus on business without worrying about the
constraints of their current technology architecture.

_Focus on R&D and Investment in Product Portfolio_

Since 2020, we have invested $521 million in R&D initiatives. With nearly 1,900 Rocketeer Engineers (pro forma for
the AMC Acquisition) and an R&D presence in five continents, our R&D investment is the cornerstone of our ability
to innovate, enabling us to better address customer needs, retain existing accounts and attract new business. It also
allows us to provide full-stack solutions to our customers, which we believe, in conjunction with our powerful GTM
team and strategy, will ultimately drive strong retention rates among our installed bases. Our customer-centric R&D
shows our true understanding of the different needs of our customers and buyers who are looking to modernize their
infrastructure, reinforcing, and magnifying our commitment to innovation. Additionally, because we’ve scaled the
business so significantly through both organic and inorganic growth, we’ve managed to achieve significant scale
efficiency in our R&D investments.

_Support Full-Stack Modernization and Tap into Multiple Budget Pools_

We provide a full-stack of infrastructure, application, and data modernization solutions, allowing companies to
integrate legacy and distributed systems with modern cloud capabilities. This full-stack of IT system modernization
solutions allows us to tap into multiple budget pools, including those covered by the CIO, Chief Data Officer, Head
of Applications, Chief Information Security Officer, Head of Infrastructure and more. With our suite of products and
solutions, we can help companies ensure that their existing infrastructure is able to successfully deliver digital
transformation initiatives and provide competitive advantages; deliver new mission-critical applications across hybrid
infrastructures; govern and access key data and content to strengthen customer relationships and ensure compliance;
and drive key initiatives to secure and protect data across the broader enterprise. This multi-layered approach opens
corporate budgets beyond the mainframe and infrastructure-centric buyer and expands our wallet share to larger digital
transformation initiatives that we can access through upsell and cross-sell opportunities.


-----

_Maintain Our Strong Operational Efficiency and Profitability_

Our focus on operational efficiency and disciplined expense management has helped us to maintain consistently high
Adjusted EBITDA margins. This commitment to cost control has enabled our ongoing investments in R&D to further
expand our solution footprint. We believe this continued emphasis on cost control results in attractive operating
leverage and cash flow generation.

_Pursue Accretive Acquisitions to Further Supplement Our Portfolio_

Over our history, we have completed more than 50 acquisitions and developed a track record of successfully
integrating acquired companies. Acquisitions have historically been completed at attractive multiples and have
allowed us to further enhance our product portfolio. Our multi-prong approach to evaluating potential acquisitions
includes identification of (1) Solution Enhancement, (2) Solution Expansion and (3) Synergy Realization, which
allows us to be intentional and methodical throughout both the discovery and vetting processes. We focus on
opportunities that accelerate the development of important underinvested functionalities, provide cross-selling
opportunities, and rationalize costs through scale.

**Our Industry**

We view our business as having three distinct addressable markets, each of which is aligned with a specific business
unit. While these markets are distinct in nature, there is a common thread in that the environment and underlying
technology are deeply embedded and responsible for organizations’ most mission-critical functions. We expect the
AMC Acquisition to further build out our product capabilities to address all customer use cases, and we will integrate
the AMC business’s products into our existing business units. While investment in legacy systems has been stable,
companies are increasing their spend across modernization, integration, hybridization and next-generation data
applications. We are positioned to serve as a modernization partner that taps into growing budget pools focused on
digital transformation across a suite of buyers with evergreen budget pools including the CIO, Chief Data Officer,
Head of Applications and Head of Infrastructure. In aggregate, we view our current total addressable market as $24
billion, which sits within a broader $3.9 trillion digital transformation market. Our three current addressable markets
are as follows:

  - _Mainframe and Hybrid Cloud Software: Our infrastructure modernization products support customers in_
optimizing their mainframe workloads across a broad spectrum of pathways. Based on third-party market
research, we estimate the current market related to mainframe and hybrid cloud software to be approximately
$11 billion. Going forward, this market is expected to grow at approximately 4% annually. We believe we
have an approximately 4% market share of this addressable market. For most of our customers, the embedded
nature of mainframe servers and the speed, size and security requirements of the workloads being run on
them make switching away from the mainframe an expensive and difficult process. The importance of
mainframe is evidenced by the fact that approximately 70% of the world’s production IT workloads are
handled by mainframes. According to IBM, over $8 trillion in payments per year, and over 30 billion
transactions per day, are processed by mainframes. Mainframe criticality is driven by the need for reliability,
with many applications requiring high availability, and the complexity and vastness of the underlying code
makes mainframe integral to operations. There are a range of advantages that mainframe offers over
distributed computing including reliability, speed of computing and security. For customers who remain on
the mainframe, the increased data requirements and volumes generated by the digitalization of businesses
will lead to increasing mainframe workloads. For example, when retail bank account holders check their
account or engage in online banking, this activity results in queries to the mainframe creating additional
mainframe transaction volume. As retail banks and other institutions increase their product offerings and
continue their digital transformation initiatives, the ability to connect and interact with the mainframe will be
an important component of most IT deployments. Higher workload volume combined with the ongoing need
to operate, optimize, and modernize the mainframe should provide continued growth opportunities within
our Infrastructure Modernization business unit.


-----

We expect the AMC Acquisition to expand our product offerings in the mainframe and hybrid cloud market
with Enterprise Suite, COBOL and Mainframe ADLM, enabling further modernization of mainframe
applications and hybrid cloud infrastructure. With the largest companies in the world across every major
industry vertical continuing to leverage mainframe technology through hybrid cloud models, we expect that
hybrid infrastructure will remain the architecture of choice. By enabling core IT infrastructure to continue
living in mainframe environments while leveraging APIs that provide teams and customers with access to
cloud solutions and web and mobile applications, businesses are providing a modern experience for
employees and end-users, without taking on additional risk.

  - _Enterprise Content Management (“ECM”): Data modernization solutions enable organizations to capture,_
build, organize, manage and store enterprise documents and records. Using third-party market research, we
estimate the current market related to ECM solutions to be approximately $5 billion. Going forward, this
market is forecasted to grow at approximately 6% annually. Enterprises need to securely manage documents
and records across their organization and require software that provides tools to capture, build, organize,
manage and store documents and records as they flow through business processes. ECM modernization tools
for mainframe-based enterprises allow organizations to utilize terabytes of stored data that are typically
inaccessible and unutilized. Common applications of ECM systems for our customers involve document
generation workloads, which include invoice and statement generation and ticket issuance. More advanced
processes include document ingestion, robotic process automation and workflow management. For example,
processing a mortgage application is a complex process involving multiple steps and systems, which can be
streamlined and automated with an ECM system. ECM solutions are often embedded in core customer facing
workflows and are integrated with other core IT systems (enterprise resource planning systems, customer
relationship management systems, financial systems, etc.) that leverage other mainframe-stored content. The
critical nature and deep integration of ECM workflows should continue to drive future growth within our
Data Modernization business unit.

  - _App Development & Testing: Our application modernization solutions enable organizations to extract data_
from legacy Unix/Power Systems, modernize the experience for users and enable the usability of large scale
non-relational databases. Based on third-party market research, we estimate the current market related to
application development and testing to be approximately $8 billion. Going forward, this market is forecasted
to grow by approximately 5% annually. Organizations use application modernization products to improve
application responsiveness and engagement across hybrid environments by creating modern workflows for
legacy applications in a safe and secure way. Common uses of application modernization products include
enabling application development on top of mission-critical non-relational databases, removing complexity
from building modern apps on legacy platforms with low- or no-code solutions and supporting agile DevOps
methods across multiple legacy coding environments. Continued investment in functionality that supports
cloud and containerized app deployments, organizations improving application UI/UX and a shift to low- or
no-code development concepts should provide continued growth opportunities within our Application
Modernization business unit. The AMC business’s Host Connectivity and CORBA segments offer
complementary modernization solutions enabling Rocket to provide a more comprehensive solution to our
customers and increase our share in the application and development testing market.

**The AMC Acquisition**

_Acquisition Agreement_

On November 28, 2023, we entered into a Purchase Agreement (the “Acquisition Agreement”) with OpenText, pursuant
to which OpenText has agreed to divest, directly and indirectly through certain subsidiaries, its AMC business and we
have agreed to purchase the same and generally assume certain liabilities related to the AMC business, as set forth in
the Acquisition Agreement, for an all-cash purchase price of $2.275 billion, before taxes, fees and other adjustments.

The Acquisition Agreement contains customary representations, warranties and covenants for a transaction of this type,
including a covenant providing for each of the parties to use reasonable efforts to cause the AMC Acquisition to be
consummated. Subject to certain limitations, the Company and OpenText have also agreed to indemnify each other for
certain liabilities that have been specifically allocated between the parties. The Company and OpenText will also enter
into a Transition Services Agreement at the closing of the AMC Acquisition, pursuant to which OpenText and its
affiliates will provide support for a period of up to 24 months from the closing of the AMC Acquisition to the Company
in connection with the AMC business.

_The Financing Transactions_

In connection with the AMC Acquisition, we intend to consummate the following financing transactions:

 - the issuance of $1,000 million in aggregate principal amount of the notes offered hereby;

 - (i) the amendment of certain terms of the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein) to,
among other things, (v) increase the aggregate principal amount of commitments by approximately $222
million to approximately $375 million, (w) extend the maturity date of certain of the revolving commitments
thereunder from November 28, 2026 to August 29, 2028 (the “Extended First Lien Revolving Credit Facility”),
(x) increase the applicable margin for adjusted SOFR to 4.00%, (y) increase the first lien net leverage ratio
financial covenant, to an amount not to exceed 8.00 to 1.00 and (z) add requirements for certain of our
subsidiaries incorporated under the laws of England and Wales to guarantee and secure the obligations under
the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and (ii) enter into (x) a Euro-denominated incremental term loan facility
(the “Euro Incremental Term Loan Facility”) under the credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term
Loans (as defined herein) and (y) a U.S. dollar-denominated term loan facility (the “USD Incremental Term
Loan Facility” and, together with the Euro Incremental Term Loan Facility, the “Incremental First Lien Term
Loan Facilities” and, together with the Extended First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, the “Incremental Senior
Secured Credit Facilities”) in the form of a side car term loan facility or an incremental term loan facility under
the credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term Loans, as applicable, in a combined aggregate
principal amount of $1,000 million (reflecting U.S. dollar-equivalent for the Euro Incremental Term Loan
Facility), in each case with a syndicate of lenders, that will rank pari passu with the Existing First Lien Term
Loans and that will mature on November 28, 2028; and

 - the cash contribution of approximately $200 million in common equity directly or indirectly to the Company
or a parent entity of the Company by certain investment funds affiliated with Bain Capital along with any
additional co-investors designated by Bain Capital (including existing equityholders of the Company), the cash
proceeds of which will be further contributed to the Company (the “Equity Contribution” and, collectively with
the offering of the notes, the incurrence of the Incremental Senior Secured Credit Facilities and, in each case,
the use of proceeds therefrom, the “Financing Transactions”).

We intend to use the net proceeds from the offering of the notes, together with borrowings under our Incremental First
Lien Term Loan Facilities, proceeds from the Equity Contribution and cash on hand, to (i) finance and consummate
the AMC Acquisition and (ii) pay transaction expenses and fees in connection with the foregoing.

In this offering memorandum, we refer to the AMC Acquisition and the Financing Transactions collectively as the
“Transactions.”

(1) In addition to our results under GAAP, we also present our Non-GAAP Metrics, which are non-GAAP
financial measures and have been presented in this offering memorandum as supplemental measures of
financial performance that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, GAAP. We define our nonGAAP financial measures as follows:

        - Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue is revenue resulting from the annualized value of invoices for
active maintenance and term/subscription contracts (including expired contracts that have a
high probability of renewal within twelve months of the previously ended term) as of the last
day of the reporting period, plus royalty, perpetual license, professional service and other
revenue calculated on a last-twelve-month basis. Revenue is reported on a pro forma basis
(including the historical financial performance of acquisitions prior to the applicable acquisition
date for all periods presented) and excludes the impact of purchase accounting adjustments for
deferred revenue and backlog intangible asset amortization;


-----

    - Non-GAAP Cost of Revenue is cost of revenue, excluding amortization of acquired technology
and employee stock compensation and other one-time expenses and including certain pro forma
cost of revenue adjustments.

    - Non-GAAP Gross Profit is Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue less Non-GAAP Cost of Revenue,
which is GAAP cost of revenue adjusted for amortization of intangible assets, stock
compensation and other, and certain pro forma adjustments (including the historical financial
performance of acquisitions prior to the applicable acquisition date for all periods presented);

    - EBITDA is net income (loss), excluding interest expense, other income (expense), employee
stock compensation expense, income taxes and depreciation and amortization expenses;

    - Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is EBITDA, on a pro forma basis (including the historical
financial performance of acquisitions prior to the applicable acquisition date for all periods
presented), adjusted for Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue, and excluding costs or income relating
to acquisitions, debt refinancing, management consulting, recruiting, employee termination and
severance, restructuring, litigation, new product design and development, and other items that
are considered non-core to business operations;

    - Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA is Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as further adjusted to give
effect to restructuring activities and planned synergies related to certain acquisitions, including,
as indicated, with and without, the AMC Acquisition;

    - Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA Margin is Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA divided by
Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue;

    - Free Cash Flow is Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA less capital expenditures, inclusive of
financing lease payments; and

    - Free Cash Flow Conversion is Free Cash Flow divided by Pro Forma Run Rate Cash EBITDA.

Certain of our Non-GAAP Metrics in this section have been calculated utilizing accounting principles not
consistent with GAAP, including recognizing revenue on an ARR basis rather than in accordance with ASC
606. A primary difference between ARR and ASC 606 is the accounting for license revenue in our
subscription or term license arrangements, which is annualized and recognized over the contract term under
our ARR method, while recognized at a point in time, generally at the inception of the contract term, under
ASC 606. Our Non-GAAP Metrics should not be considered as alternatives to net income (loss), revenue or
other measures of performance derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or
operating cash flows or as measures of liquidity.

We believe that these measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating performance from period
to period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. We believe
that they provide investors with a useful tool for assessing the comparability between periods of our ability
to generate cash from operations sufficient to pay taxes, to service debt and to undertake capital expenditures.
We use these measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to that of
our competitors.

Our use of the Non-GAAP metrics varies from others in our industry. Non-GAAP Metrics have important
limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of
our results as reported under GAAP.

**_The AMC Business_**

In light of the significance of the AMC Acquisition, this offering memorandum includes audited combined carveout
financial statements of the AMC business as of and for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022. OpenText
acquired Micro Focus on January 31, 2023. The AMC business has historically operated as part of Micro Focus or,
following acquisition thereof, OpenText and not as a standalone company. The audited combined carveout financial
statements of the AMC business included elsewhere in this offering memorandum are presented on a “carve-out” basis
from (i) Micro Focus’s accounting records for the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023 and (ii) OpenText’s
accounting records for the period from and after February 1, 2023, using the historical results of operations, cash
flows, assets and liabilities of the AMC business. For the period from January 1, 2022 to January 31, 2023, the audited
combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business exclude OT Connectivity. The audited combined
carveout financial statements of the AMC business include allocations of corporate expenses and shared expenses
from Micro Focus and OpenText, as applicable, and may not fully reflect what the AMC business’s financial position,
results of operations or cash flows would have been had it been a standalone company during the periods presented.
As a result, the audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business included elsewhere in this
offering memorandum are not necessarily indicative of the AMC business’s future results of operations, financial
position or cash flows. The audited combined carveout financial statements of the AMC business were prepared in
accordance with GAAP.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below and_
_all of the information included in this offering memorandum before deciding whether to purchase the notes. Any of_
_the following risks may materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition._
_The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties that we face. Additional risks and_
_uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial may also materially and adversely affect_
_our business, results of operations and financial condition. In such a case, you may lose all or part of your original_
_investment. The risks discussed below also include forward–looking statements, and our actual results may differ_
_substantially from those discussed in these forward–looking statements. See “Forward–looking Statements” in this_
_offering memorandum._

**Risks Related to our Business**

**_We derive a significant portion of our revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM and loss of_**
**_significant revenue from this partnership would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,_**
**_results of operations and prospects._**

We derive a significant portion of our revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM. For the fiscal years
ended December 31, 2023 and 2022 and the pro forma combined fiscal year ended December 31, 2023, we generated
approximately 38%, 35% and 23%, respectively, of our total Non-GAAP Adjusted Revenue from this partnership. No
other customer or partner accounted for more than 3% of our total revenue during the fiscal years ended December
31, 2023 and 2022.

We are a party to a master licensed works agreement (the “MLWA”) with IBM to develop and update mission-critical
software products for IBM’s core platforms. IBM is not obligated under the MLWA to issue new statements of work
or work orders to us, nor is IBM required to spend a minimum amount with us in any period. As a result, there can be
no assurance that the volume of work to be performed by us under the MLWA and the revenue we generate therefrom
will not vary significantly from year to year, which could in turn cause our revenue to vary significantly from year to
year and could potentially decrease in the future by material amounts. We may experience loss or reduction of business
under the MLWA for any reason, including the royalties received for and quality of the products and services we
provide. In addition, IBM has its own policies and guidelines that control its promotion and distribution practices and,
pursuant to the terms of the MLWA, has the ability to change unilaterally how they promote and/or distribute the
products we build for them. Accordingly, IBM may reduce prices to its end users, which would reduce the
corresponding royalties to us. IBM may also demand increased quality standards or, under certain circumstances,
transfer some or all of the work and services we currently provide in-house or to our current or future competitors.
Alternatively, unexpected adverse events affecting the financial condition or business strategy of IBM could result in
a reduction or delay in work orders from or a delay or default in payment by IBM. Our future growth will depend in
part on IBM’s ability to market and sell our products and services and the loss of significant revenue under this
partnership would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and
prospects.

**_If customers do not renew their contracts with us, our revenue will decline, and our business and financial_**
**_condition may be adversely affected._**

Renewals of existing maintenance contracts and subscriptions are handled primarily by our centralized renewal team,
who have helped to drive our consistently high gross and net retention rates, which have averaged 92% and 102%,
respectively, since 2020. However, these retention rates may decline or fluctuate in the future. In order for us to
maintain or improve our results of operations, it is important that our customers renew their maintenance contracts
and subscriptions when existing terms expire. Our customers have no obligation to renew after the expiration of their
contractual period and in the normal course of business, some customers have elected not to renew.

Our direct sales force for our Rocket-branded products develops relationships directly with our customers. Our
enterprise sales professionals focus on building long term relationships with key customers, minimizing cancellations
and maximizing renewal revenue, while our product specialists identify new opportunities for additional capacity.


-----

**_If we are unable to attract new customers or convert our single-product customers into multi-product customers in_**
**_a manner that is cost-effective, our growth could be slower than we expect, and our business may be harmed._**

Demand for our products is affected by a number of factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as continued
market acceptance of our products, the timing of development and release of new features and functions, technological
change, growth or contraction in our addressable market, operating systems and applications and macroeconomic
changes on the demand for technology solutions like ours. In addition, if competitors introduce lower cost or
differentiated products or services that are perceived to compete with our features, our ability to sell our features based
on factors such as pricing, technology and functionality could be impaired. As a result, we may be unable to attract
new customers at rates or on terms that would be favorable or comparable to prior periods, which could negatively
affect the growth of our revenue. Even if we do attract customers, the cost of new customer acquisition may prove so
high as to prevent us from achieving or sustaining profitability.

Our sales efforts typically involve educating our prospective customers about the uses, benefits and value proposition
of the systems and applications that our products support. Customers often view these commitments as significant
strategic decisions and, as a result, may require time to evaluate, test and qualify our solutions prior to entering into
or expanding a relationship with us or acquiring new products from our portfolio. We spend substantial time and
resources on our sales efforts without any assurance that our efforts will produce a sale. The failure of our efforts to
secure sales after investing resources in a sales process could materially and adversely affect our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Additionally, the increased complexity and expansion of our customers’ IT infrastructures have driven additional
usage of our installed solutions and provided opportunities to sell additional products from our portfolio and has
caused us to invest in sales efforts focused on cross-selling and upselling existing customers. If our upsell and crosssell efforts do not result in additional revenue, we may not experience growth and our business, results of operations
and financial condition may be adversely affected.

**_We may not realize or sustain the expected benefits from our business transformation initiatives, and these efforts_**
**_could have a materially adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, results of operations and_**
**_competitive position._**

We have been and will be undertaking certain transformation initiatives, which are designed to streamline our
organization and strengthen our talent and culture, while supporting our revenue growth, margin improvement and
productivity. If we do not successfully manage and execute these initiatives, or if they are inadequate or ineffective,
we may fail to meet our financial goals and achieve anticipated benefits, improvements may be delayed, not sustained
or not realized and our business, operations and competitive position could be adversely affected. These initiatives, or
our failure to successfully manage them, could result in unintended consequences or unforeseen costs, including
distraction of our management and employees, attrition, inability to attract or retain key personnel and reduced
employee productivity, which could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_If we do not accurately predict, prepare for and respond promptly to rapidly evolving technological and market_**
**_developments, our competitive position and business prospects may be harmed._**

We need to continue to provide critical functionality as customers’ IT innovation evolves. The markets in which we
compete have evolved rapidly, and the pace of innovation will continue to accelerate as hybrid cloud, open source,
mobile, workflow, consumer product-like user experiences, social, collaboration, machine learning, AI, internet
connected devices, robotic automation, security, cryptography, development tools and other digital technologies
increasingly become the basis for customer purchases. At the same time, our customers and prospective customers are
facing their own competitive imperatives to adopt digital technologies, resulting in the ongoing disruption of almost
every sector of the global economy.

Accordingly, to compete effectively in our rapidly changing markets, we must:

    - identify and invest in the right emerging technologies and select them from the many technologies in
which we could make investments;


-----

    - accurately predict our customers’ changing business needs;

    - successfully deliver new platform technologies and products that meet these business needs;

    - efficiently integrate with other technologies within our customers’ digital environments;

    - profitably market and sell new products in markets where our sales and marketing teams have less
experience; and

    - effectively deliver, either directly or through our ecosystem of partners, the business process planning,
IT systems architecture planning and product implementation services that our customers require to be
successful.

Further, as new technologies (such as AI) continue to emerge, they may be disruptive to our industry as a whole. These
technologies could result in new and innovative products and solutions that could increase competition, place us at a
competitive disadvantage or even render our technology, products and solutions obsolete. As the adoption of AI
quickens, we expect competition to intensify, and additional companies may enter our markets offering similar
products, systems or solutions. We may not be able to compete effectively with our competitors and our strategy to
integrate AI and other machine learning technology into our products, systems or solutions may also not be accepted
by our customers or by other businesses in the marketplace.

If we fail to meet any of these requirements or develop these technologies or our competitors or other third parties
respond to such challenges more quickly or successfully than us, the demand for our solutions and services may
diminish and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Disruptions of, discovery of errors in or risks related to our software solutions could adversely affect our financial_**
**_condition._**

The software solutions we offer are inherently complex. Despite testing and quality control, we cannot be certain that
errors will not be found in current versions, new versions or enhancements of our solutions after commencement of
commercial delivery. If new or existing customers have difficulty deploying our products or require significant
amounts of customer support, our operating margins could be harmed. In addition, any disruptions, discovery of errors,
risks related to our software solutions or other performance problems could significantly harm their and our reputations
and businesses. With our current solutions strategy, these risks increase because we are combining already complex
products to create solutions that are even more complicated than the aggregation of their product components.
Significant technical challenges could also arise with our solutions, because our customers purchase and deploy our
products across a variety of computer platforms and integrate them with a number of third-party software applications
and databases. These combinations increase our risk, with respect to our customers, because, in the event of a systemwide failure, it may be difficult for the customer to determine which product is at fault; thus, we may be blamed for
the failure of another supplier’s products.

As a result of the foregoing, we could experience loss of or delay in revenue and loss of market share, loss of
customers, damage to our reputation, an increase in our provision for doubtful accounts, higher development and
testing and support costs, failure to achieve market acceptance, diversion of development and support resources,
increased service and warranty costs, litigation and increased insurance costs.

**_Cyber-attacks on our networks and actual or perceived security vulnerabilities in our products and services could_**
**_have an adverse impact on our business and results of operations._**

Increasingly, companies are subject to a wide variety of cyber-attacks on their systems and networks on an ongoing
basis. In the course of our regular business operations, we process and transmit personal information, proprietary
information, confidential information and other sensitive or regulated data, including personal information of
employees, customers and others. Computer programmers, hackers and other third parties may be able to penetrate
our network security and misappropriate, copy or pirate the information and data we collect (including that of third
parties), create system disruptions or cause interruptions or shutdowns of our internal systems and services. A number
of websites have been subject to denial of service attacks, where a website is bombarded with information requests


-----

eventually causing the website to overload, resulting in a delay or disruption of service. Also, in recent years, there
has been a growing trend of advanced persistent threats being launched by organized and coordinated groups against
corporate networks to breach their security for malicious purposes. These attacks may be committed by company
employees or external actors operating in any geography, including jurisdictions where law enforcement measures to
address such attacks are unavailable or ineffective and may even be launched by or at the behest of nation states. If
successful, any of these events could damage our computer systems and equipment or those of our third-party hosting
vendors or customers. Furthermore, these attacks could disrupt or prevent us from providing timely maintenance,
support and services to our customers and result in the theft or misappropriation of proprietary, personally identifiable,
confidential and other sensitive or regulated information and data of ours, our employees, our customers and our
business partners and materially disrupt business for us, our customers and our business partners.

Computer programmers, hackers and other third parties also may be able to develop and deploy viruses, worms and
other malicious software programs that attack our products or otherwise exploit any security vulnerabilities of our
products. The costs to us to eliminate or alleviate security problems, bugs, viruses, worms, malicious software
programs and security vulnerabilities could be significant and the efforts to address these problems could result in
interruptions, delays, cessation of service and loss of existing or potential customers and may impede our sales and
other critical functions. Security risks for us will also increase as we continue to grow our offerings and services,
especially in customer sectors involving particularly sensitive data. Additionally, our customers may not effectively
implement all of the updated security features that we introduce or make all necessary changes to their operating
