**ROCKET’S MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND**

**RESULTS OF OPERATIONS**

_The following management discussion and analysis of the Company’s financial condition and results of operations_
_should be read in conjunction with the section of this offering memorandum captioned “Business” and the Company’s_
_audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes to those statements included elsewhere in this offering_
_memorandum. In addition to historical financial information, the following discussion and analysis contains forward-_
_looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Actual results and timing of selected events may_
_differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including_
_those discussed under the sections of this offering memorandum captioned “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk_
_Factors.”_

**Overview**

Rocket Software, Inc. is a leading global enterprise software provider with a broad portfolio of products that help
corporations, government agencies and other organizations operate, optimize and modernize their mission-critical IT
infrastructure. The Company’s software solutions run, optimize, and protect customers’ servers and databases, as well
as connect their systems to the rest of the enterprise. The products the Company provides enable customers to carry
out their most mission-critical business functions, such as processing payment transactions at global financial
institutions and maintaining healthcare records at hospitals and insurance companies. Since the Company’s founding
over 30 years ago, the Company has cultivated a customer-centric culture with strategic investments in research and
development that provide a wide range of offerings to continuously meet customers’ evolving needs.

Rocket meets customers wherever they are on their modernization journeys—whether modernizing on premise or
through a hybrid cloud strategy. With over 10,000 global customers, Rocket solves enterprises’ most complex IT
challenges, across infrastructure, data and applications.

**_Recent and Pending Acquisitions_**

On November 28, 2023, Rocket entered into the Acquisition Agreement with OpenText, pursuant to which OpenText
has agreed to divest, directly and indirectly through certain subsidiaries, its AMC business and Rocket has agreed to
purchase the same and generally assume certain liabilities related to the AMC business, as set forth in the Acquisition
Agreement, for an all-cash purchase price of $2.275 billion, before taxes, fees and other adjustments.

On August 31, 2023, Rocket, through its wholly owned subsidiary, Rocket Software Deutschland GmbH, acquired
100% of the equity interest in BOS DigiTec GmbH (“BOS”), a private company based in Munich, Germany for a
purchase price of $17.8 million, net of cash acquired of $4.9 million.

On February 28, 2023, the Company acquired 100% of the equity interest in Key Resources, Inc. (“KRI”) for a
purchase price of $2.2 million, net of cash acquired of $0.1 million.

The KRI purchase agreement includes contingent payments of up to $4.0 million, payable to two former shareholders
of KRI in annual installments over a three-year period following the closing date, to the extent certain financial
performance and employee retention conditions are met. The Company has determined the contingent payments to be
a post-combination compensation arrangement and will accrue for the expected cost over the period in which the
compensation is considered probable and earned. As of December 31, 2023, the Company has accrued $2.2 million
of expense which is recorded in General and administrative expenses within the statement of operations.

**Key Components of Results of Operations**

The following discussion describes certain line items in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.


-----

**_Revenues_**

The Company generates revenues from the sale of enterprise software products and solutions through branded direct
sales to enterprise customers that help corporations, government agencies and other organizations reach their
technology and business goals. The Company also licenses products to original equipment manufacturer (“OEM”)
partners, predominantly represented by IBM, independent software vendor (“ISV”) partners, reseller partners; to
provide partners and customers solutions, features, and flexibility through service and support businesses; and to
acquire and integrate businesses with similar technology, customers, platforms, and sales channels.

Revenue growth is dependent on the ability to sell software products with maintenance and support. License revenue
consists of products sold on a perpetual or fixed term basis that generally ranges from one to five years. Maintenance
revenue consists of technical support, bug fixes, and when-and-if available unspecified software upgrades.
Maintenance contracts generally have an annual term with optional renewal terms or may be bundled in a fixed term
license arrangement. Subscription revenue consists of several software as a service (“SaaS”) hosted offerings and
OEM royalty revenue. SaaS hosted offerings are sold via a subscription-based model. Professional service revenue
consists primarily of consulting and training services and may be bundled or sold on a stand-alone basis.

**_Cost of Revenues and Gross Profit_**

Cost of revenue consists primarily of salaries, benefits and bonuses for employees directly associated with customer
support, software purchased for resale, and amortization of acquired intangibles for purchased technology. Gross profit
may vary from quarter to quarter and is primarily affected by revenue and purchased technology amortization, which
varies based on the timing of acquisitions and the related fair values determined in purchase accounting.

**_Operating Expense_**

**_Research and Development_**

Research and development expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs for the design and development of
technology and contractor costs to supplement staff levels. The Company devotes substantial resources to research
and development in an effort to maintain a competitive position. The Company expects that research and development
expense will increase as its business grows, particularly as the Company incurs additional costs related to continued
investments in its platform and products.

**_Sales and Marketing_**

Sales and marketing expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs directly associated with sales and marketing
staff and commissions. Other sales and marketing costs include marketing programs and promotional events to
promote the Company’s brands. Certain sales commissions earned by the sales force are deferred and amortized on a
straight-line basis over the period of contract performance or a longer period, generally the expected life of the
customer relationship. The expected customer relationship period is determined based on average historical customer
relationship periods, including expected renewals. Expected renewal periods are only included in the expected
customer relationship period if commission amounts paid upon renewal are not commensurate with amounts paid on
the initial contract. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs incurred to obtain a contract that
would not have been incurred if the contract had not been obtained. The Company has determined that certain
commissions programs meet the requirements to be deferred. The Company groups similar contracts based on revenue
and customer type and amortizes commissions on a systemic basis over the average contract length or expected
customer life.

**_General and Administrative_**

General and administrative expenses consist primarily of employee-related costs for executive, finance, legal, human
resources, IT, and administrative personnel, professional fees for external legal, accounting, recruiting and other
consulting services, facility costs, and depreciation of property and equipment. These expenses also include
management fees payable to Bain Capital Private Equity, LP.


-----

**_Amortization of Other Acquired Intangible Assets_**

Amortization of other acquired intangible assets consists primarily of the amortization of acquired intangible assets,
excluding amortization of purchased technology and backlog. Amortization may vary from quarter to quarter and is
primarily affected by acquired intangible assets, which varies based on the timing of acquisitions and the related fair
values determined in purchase accounting.

**_Non-Operating Expenses_**

**_Interest Expense_**

Interest expense consists primarily of contractual interest expense on long-term debt, including senior notes, a first
lien term loan, a first lien revolving line of credit, acquired debt from the 2019 acquisition of Sixon Holding SA, and
the amortization of debt issuance costs. As discussed in _Note 15, Derivatives, to the audited consolidated financial_
statements for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Company entered into interest rate swaps and caps
for a portion of debt, and the realized gains or losses from those derivatives are recorded as a component of interest
expense. The Company expects interest expense to decrease when indebtedness is repaid or when interest rate fall.
The Company expects interest expense to increase when indebtedness is borrowed and when interest rates rise.

**_Other Income (Expense), Net_**

Other income (expense), net consists primarily of gains and losses on sale of investments, foreign currency
transactions and remeasurements, and remeasurements or settlements of non-hedge designated derivative instruments.
The Company’s reporting currency is the U.S. dollar. With respect to non-U.S. subsidiaries, the functional currency
is the local currency.

**_Provision (Benefit) for Income Taxes_**

Provision (benefit) for income taxes consists of US federal, state, and foreign income taxes related to the jurisdictions
in which the Company operates. Deferred income taxes are provided for differences between the financial statement
and tax basis of assets and liabilities and for tax net operating loss and credit carry forwards using enacted tax rates
expected to be in effect in the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. Valuation allowances are provided
for deferred tax assets that, based on currently available evidence, may not be realized. The Company records a liability
associated with an uncertain tax position if it is determined that there is not a more likely than not possibility of
sustaining such benefit upon audit by the taxing authority based on the technical merits of the position. The Company
records a tax benefit of a position as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being
realized upon ultimate settlement.

**_Restructuring Plans_**

In December 2023, the Company announced its decision to exit its operations in China as a broader initiative to colocate many of its application modernization products at the Company’s development centers located in Vilnius,
Lithuania; Pune, India; and Bentonville, Arkansas.

The estimated cost of the program is $16.0 to $18.0 million and it is expected to be completed in early 2025. The
Company recorded $7.3 million of employee-related restructuring costs within operating expenses in the fourth quarter
of 2023. The plan is not expected to generate savings.

In July 2023, the Company’s management approved a plan to reduce its global workforce by approximately 5%. The
plan was substantially completed during the quarter ended September 30, 2023 at a cost of $6.4 million. Upon
completion of the plan, the Company expects to generate approximately $14.0 million of annualized savings.

During 2021, the Company announced a global reorganization and facilities consolidation plan to reduce redundancies
and achieve synergies relating to the integration of the Company’s acquisitions of M4 Global Solutions Holding
Coöperatief U.A. and its wholly owned subsidiary, Uniface B.V. (collectively, “Uniface”) and ASG Everglades
Holdings, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiary, ASG Technologies Holdings, Inc., ASG Technologies Group, Inc.
(collectively, “ASG”). The total cost of the plan was $57.2 million and was completed in the second quarter of 2023.
The plan included restructuring-related costs such as employee severance, other employee-related costs, asset
impairments and accelerated depreciation, facility exit costs as well as consulting fees relating to integrations. The
Company expects to generate approximately $50.0 million of annualized savings.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Cash, Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash_**

Cash and cash equivalents are primarily comprised of bank deposits and money market funds held with global
relationship banks. As of December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Company had $239.0 million and $157.8 million,
respectively, of unrestricted cash. These amounts do not include restricted cash, which primarily represents deposits
on lease facilities and are included in prepaid expense, other current assets, and other assets. The Company had net
working capital (defined as current assets less current liabilities) of $136.4 million, $88.3 million and ($3.9) million
as of December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively.

The primary sources of liquidity include existing unrestricted cash, cash flow generated from operations, and
borrowings from the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. As of December 31, 2023, the Company had $151.7
million available for additional borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, after giving effect
to $1.2 million of letters of credit issued thereunder.

As of December 31, 2023, the Company had cash requirements of $215.0 million for estimated interest payments over
the next 12 months. The Company also has cash requirements related to principal debt obligation and lease payments.
See Note 10, Long-Term Debt and Note 11, Leases to the audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere
in this offering memorandum for a description of long-term debt obligations and lease commitments, respectively.
The Company anticipates using existing cash and proceeds from operating cash flows to fund these expenditures.

Liquidity needs primarily include meeting debt service requirements, working capital requirements and capital
expenditures. The Company may also pursue strategic acquisition opportunities that may impact future cash
requirements. There are certain factors that may negatively impact available sources of funds in the future including
the ability to generate cash from operations and borrow on debt facilities. The amount of cash generated from
operations is dependent upon factors such as the successful execution of business strategies and general economic
conditions. The amount of cash available for borrowings under various debt facilities is dependent on the ability to
maintain sufficient collateral and general financial conditions in the marketplace.

**Debt Obligations**

**_Existing Credit Facilities_**

On November 28, 2018, in connection with the completion of Bain Capital’s acquisition of the Company, the
Company entered into a credit agreement with Royal Bank of Canada (as successor to Credit Suisse AG, Cayman
Islands Branch), as administrative agent, and the lenders party thereto, which, as amended through December 31,
2023, provides for (i) a first lien term loan in an aggregate principal amount of approximately $1,410 million in U.S.
dollar-denominated term loans (the “Existing Dollar Term Loan”) and an aggregate principal amount of €575 million
Euro-denominated term loans (after giving effect to amortization payments made prior to the date hereof) (the
“Existing Euro Term Loan” and, together with the Existing Dollar Term Loan, the “Existing First Lien Term Loans”),
and (ii) a revolving loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of up to approximately $152.9 million (the “Existing
First Lien Revolving Credit Facility” and, together with the Existing First Lien Term Loans, the Incremental First
Lien Term Loan Facilities (as described elsewhere) and the Extended First Lien Revolving Credit Facility, the “Senior
Secured Credit Facilities”). As of December 31, 2023, the Existing Dollar Term Loan had a balance of $1,403.9
million and the Existing Euro Term Loan, translated in U.S. dollars, had an outstanding balance of $635.2 million. As
of December 31, 2023, the Company had $152.9 million in borrowings available under the Existing First Lien
Revolving Credit Facility (without giving effect to $1 million of letters of credit issued thereunder).

Under the terms of the Existing Dollar Term Loan, the principal amount is paid in quarterly installments equal to 1.0%
of the original principal amount per annum until the final maturity date, when the remaining principal is due and
monthly floating interest rate payments are made based on the one-month SOFR rate. The interest rate per annum
applicable to the Existing Dollar Term Loan is the adjusted SOFR rate (with a minimum of 0.50% per annum) plus
4.75%.

Under the terms of the Existing Euro Term Loan, the Company will make monthly floating interest rate payments
based on the one-month EURIBOR rate. The interest rate per annum applicable to the Existing Euro Term Loan is the
adjusted EURIBOR rate (with a minimum of 0.00% per annum) plus 4.75%.


-----

The interest rate per annum applicable to borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility is, at the
option of the Company, the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.25% or the alternative base rate plus 2.25%, with step-downs
to (i) the adjusted SOFR rate plus 3.125% or the alternative base rate plus 2.125%, as applicable, and (ii) the adjusted
SOFR rate plus 3.00% or the alternative base rate plus 2.00%, as applicable, in each case based on achieving certain
First Lien Net Leverage Ratios, as defined in the credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Term Loans and
the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility.

The credit agreement governing the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility contains a financial covenant that
requires compliance with a maximum First Lien Net Leverage Ratio of 7.70 to 1.00 if, on the last day of any quarter,
the amount of borrowings under the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility is greater than 35% of the aggregate
outstanding revolving commitments. The covenant did not apply to the Company as of December 31, 2023. The
Existing First Lien Term Loans and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility contain certain mandatory
prepayment requirements, including, with respect to the Existing First Lien Term Loans, 50% (with step downs to
25% and 0% based on achieving certain leverage ratios) of annual excess cash flow greater than $15.0 million in any
fiscal year. See also “Description of Other Indebtedness.”

**_RSD Debt_**

As of August 16, 2019, the Company assumed indebtedness in connection with the acquisition of Sixon Holding SA
(the “RSD Debt”). Pursuant to the credit agreement governing the RSD Debt, dated September 19, 2018, the RSD
Debt consists of a CHF 17.5 million senior amortizing term loan facility and a CHF 17.5 million senior non-amortizing
(bullet) term loan facility. The amortizing term loan facility is subject to mandatory repayments of CHF 3.2 million,
payable annually on December 31st through 2022, with a final payment of CHF 3.2 million due on March 28, 2024
(which payment was made). The non-amortizing term loan facility, which consists of U.S. dollar-denominated
facilities and Euro-denominated facilities, has a maturity date of September 28, 2024. As of December 31, 2023, the
outstanding amount, translated into U.S. dollars, under the RSD Debt was $19.7 million.

The interest rate per annum applicable to the U.S. dollar-denominated facilities is, at the option of the Company, the
adjusted SOFR rate plus the Alternative Reference Rates Committee spread plus a blended rate of 2.6%.

The interest rate per annum applicable to the Euro-denominated facilities is, at the option of the Company, the adjusted
EURIBOR rate plus a blended rate of 2.4%.

**_Acquisitions_**

The Company accounts for business acquisitions that meet the definition of a business combination using the
acquisition method of accounting, in accordance with which assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at
their respective fair values at the acquisition date. The fair value of the consideration transferred in a business
combination, including any contingent consideration, is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based
on their respective fair values. Goodwill represents excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair values of the
assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Acquisitions that do not meet the definition of a business combination are
accounted for as asset acquisitions, and the purchase price is allocated to the net assets acquired based on their relative
fair values without recognizing goodwill. Significant judgments are used in determining fair values of assets acquired
and liabilities assumed. Fair value and intangible asset useful life determinations are based on, among other factors,
estimates of future expected cash flows, customer attrition rates, royalty cost savings and appropriate discount rates
used in computing present values. These judgments may materially impact the estimates used in allocating the
purchase price to assets acquired and liabilities assumed, as well as the Company’s current and future operating results.
Actual results may vary from these estimates which may result in adjustments to goodwill and acquisition date fair
values of assets and liabilities during a measurement period or upon a final determination of asset and liability fair
values, whichever occurs first. Adjustments to fair values of assets and liabilities made after the end of the
measurement period are recorded within the Company’s operating results.

**_Goodwill, Intangible Assets and Other Long-Lived Assets_**

Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of net tangible and
intangible assets acquired. Intangible assets consist of technology, customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames,
and backlog. Other long-lived assets generally consist of property and equipment.

The Company’s intangible assets, other than backlog and those intangible assets classified as indefinite-lived, as well
as the Company’s property and equipment, are depreciated or amortized to expense over their estimated useful lives,
or lease term, on a pattern in which the economic benefits are consumed or on a straight-line basis. Intangible assets
that are amortized to expense have estimated useful lives that range from eight to twenty-one years. Backlog is
amortized, as a reduction of revenue, on a specific identification basis following the recognition of the revenue of the
underlying contracts. Amortization of intangible assets charged to cost of revenue and operating expense for the years
ended December 31, 2023 and 2022 was $207.0 million and $206.9 million, respectively. Backlog amortization
expense recorded as a reduction of revenue was $6.2 million and $9.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2023
and 2022, respectively.

Goodwill is not subject to amortization but is tested annually for impairment or more frequently if there are indicators
of impairment. The Company performs its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, or more frequently
when events and circumstances occur indicating that the recorded goodwill may be impaired. In assessing qualitative
factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying
amount, the Company assesses relevant events and circumstances that may impact the fair value and the carrying
amount of a reporting unit. The identification of relevant events and circumstances and how these may impact a
reporting unit’s fair value or carrying amount involve significant judgments by management. These judgments include
the consideration of macroeconomic conditions, industry and market considerations, cost factors, overall financial
performance, events which are specific to the Company, and trends in the fair value of the Company’s common stock.
Each factor is assessed to determine whether it impacts the impairment test positively or negatively and the magnitude
of any such impact.


-----

The Company’s chief operating decision maker is its Chief Executive Officer. The Company, whose management
uses consolidated financial information in determining how to allocate resources and assess performance, has
determined that it has one reporting unit.

The Company performed its annual assessment of goodwill as of September 30, 2023 and 2022 on the single reporting
unit and concluded that goodwill had not been impaired.

Similar to the evaluation of those long-lived assets that are not amortized, the Company evaluates amortizable
intangible assets and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the
carrying value of an asset or asset group may not be recoverable. The Company assesses the recoverability of the
assets based on the undiscounted future cash flows the assets are expected to generate and recognizes an impairment
loss when estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to result from the use of the assets plus net proceeds
expected from disposition of the assets, if any, are less than the carrying value of the assets. If an asset or asset group
is deemed to be impaired, the amount of the impairment loss, if any, represents the excess of the asset or asset group’s
carrying value compared to its estimated fair value. Each period, the Company also evaluates the estimated remaining
useful life of its long-lived intangible assets to determine whether events or changes in circumstances warrant a
revision to the remaining period of depreciation or amortization.

A considerable amount of judgment is required in performing an impairment analysis, principally in determining
discount rates, and financial forecasts. Unanticipated changes in market conditions could have a material impact on
the Company’s projected cash flows. Differences in actual cash flows as compared to the projected cash flows, as well
as changes in market conditions, could require the Company to record additional impairment losses in the future.

**_ASC 606 Revenue Recognition_**

The guidance states that if an arrangement contains multiple performance obligations, each distinct performance
obligation is accounted for separately. Subsequently, the Company recognizes revenue through the application of the
following steps: (i) identification of the contract(s) with a customer; (ii) identification of the performance obligations
in the contract; (iii) determination of the transaction price; (iv) allocation of the transaction price to performance
obligations in the contract; and (v) recognition of revenue when or as the performance obligation is satisfied. The
Company’s policy does not permit a right of return.

_Non-OEM Revenue Recognition, Unbilled Accounts Receivable, and Deferred Revenue_

The Company’s software licenses are primarily on-premise and fully functional when made available to the customer.
As the customer can use and benefit from the license on its own, on-premise software licenses represent distinct
performance obligations. Revenue for software licenses is recognized upfront at the point in time when a license key
is delivered to a customer, and the customer may use and benefit from the license. These licenses are sold as perpetual
or for a fixed term.

Perpetual licenses are generally invoiced upon execution of the contract. Term licenses are generally invoiced upfront
or on an annual basis over the term of the arrangement, which generally range from one to five years. Any difference
between the license revenue recognized and the amount invoiced to the customer is accounted for on the consolidated
balance sheets as unbilled accounts receivable.

The Company’s maintenance service consists of technical support, bug fixes, and when-and-if available unspecified
software upgrades. As these maintenance services are considered to be a series of distinct services that are substantially
the same and have the same duration and measure of progress, the Company concludes that they represent one
combined performance obligation. Maintenance revenue is therefore recognized ratably over the contract period. Any
difference between the maintenance amount invoiced or collected and the maintenance revenue recognized is
accounted for on the consolidated balance sheets as deferred revenue.

Professional services primarily include consulting and training services. In general, services are distinct performance
obligations. Services revenue is generally recognized as the services are delivered to the customer. The Company


-----

applies the practical expedient of recognizing revenue upon invoicing for time and materials-based arrangements as
the invoiced amount corresponds to the value of the services provided.

The Company also sells several SaaS hosted offerings. These SaaS offerings are sold via a subscription-based model.
Customers can use hosted software over the contract period without taking possession of it and the services are
available to them throughout the entire term, even if they do not use the service. As the services related to this model
are indistinct from one another and have the same duration and measure of progress, revenue related to these offerings
is recognized ratably over the contract period. SaaS arrangements are generally invoiced on a monthly or quarterly
basis over the term of the arrangement.

As part of the review over the transaction price, the Company considers whether there are any variable fees, such as
usage-based arrangements, or price concessions that may give rise to variable consideration. Revenue related to
variable consideration is recorded at the time of the transfer of licenses or services to its customers.

Significant judgment is required in estimating standalone selling prices. The Company utilizes observable inputs when
they exist, such as for maintenance renewals on historical perpetual license sales, and for SaaS hosted arrangements.
The standalone selling prices of certain performance obligations, specifically the standalone selling prices for software
licenses, are highly variable. In these instances, the Company estimates a narrow range of standalone selling prices
using observable pricing information, such as the Company’s existing price list and historical sales data.

When bundled term license and maintenance sales occur, the Company bifurcates the transaction into its two separate
performance obligations, and then allocates the transaction value accordingly. The Company’s allocation between the
term license and maintenance performance obligations is calculated based upon the observable relationship of the
selling price of a standalone maintenance renewal to the related perpetual license fee, which is generally 20% of the
net license fee for one year of maintenance. The Company considers using the observable relationship between a
perpetual license fee and a standalone maintenance renewal to be appropriate for allocating value within a bundled
arrangement because the nature of the respective performance obligations and the rights transferred to the customer
are similar.

As part of the allocation of the transaction price among performance obligations, the Company considers the presence
of any material rights or specified future upgrades that could represent additional performance obligations. The
Company did not identify any material right performance obligations in the periods presented.

_OEM Revenue Recognition_

Consistent with ASC 606, the Company recognizes royalty revenue to which it is entitled in the period in which it is
earned. The Company utilizes customer information and other sources of information to determine the most likely
estimate of royalty revenue to be recognized and accrued each period. As a management estimate, the determination
of sales based royalty revenue requires significant judgment. In the event of any material difference between the
estimate and the actual royalty received, the Company will record an adjustment in the period the revenue was earned.

**_Deferred Commissions_**

The Company’s incremental costs of obtaining a contract which consist of sales commissions, are deferred, and
amortized over the period of contract performance or a longer period, generally the expected life of the customer
relationship. The expected customer relationship period is determined based on average historical customer
relationship periods, including expected renewals. Expected renewal periods are only included in the expected
customer relationship period if commission amounts paid upon renewal are not commensurate with amounts paid on
the initial contract. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs the Company incurs to obtain a
contract that it would not have incurred if the contract had not been obtained. The Company groups similar contracts
based on revenue and customer type and amortizes on a systemic basis over the average contract length or expected
customer life.

**_Qualitative Risks to Revenue Recognition_**


-----

Because a portion of the Company’s business is conducted outside of the U.S., there exists the risk of exposure to
movements in foreign currency exchange rates. International sales are usually denominated in foreign currencies, and
changes in the value of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar could adversely affect revenue results. However,
as most of the Company’s revenue comes from North American entities that operate in U.S. dollars, this is not deemed
to be a significant risk.

The Company also derives a portion of its revenues from contracts with federal, state, local, and foreign governments
and agencies. These customers operate based upon allocated budgets and appropriations. In the event that a
government or agency enters into a multi-year contract and does not receive its expected allocated budget, it is possible
that the existing contract could be terminated. However, the Company’s standard practice is for any multi-year contract
to contain a substantive termination penalty, which provides evidence of enforceable rights and obligations throughout
the stated contract term. Therefore, this is not seen to be a significant risk to revenue recognition.

**_Income Taxes_**

Deferred income taxes represent differences between the financial statement and tax basis of the Company’s assets
and liabilities and for tax net operating loss and credit carry forwards using enacted tax rates expected to be in effect
in the years in which the differences are expected to reverse. The Company calculates and recognizes deferred tax
assets and liabilities based on expected future tax consequences of these temporary differences. Valuation allowances
are calculated for the amount of deferred tax assets that, based on currently available evidence, may not be realized.

For uncertain tax positions, the Company records a liability associated with an uncertain tax position if the Company
determines that there is not a more likely than not possibility of sustaining such benefit upon audit by the taxing
authority based on the technical merits of the position. The Company records a tax benefit of a position as the largest
amount of benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement. This process
involves significant judgments on the part of management.

**_Research and Development and External Capitalized Software Development Costs_**

In accordance with ASC 730, the Company expenses costs associated with the development of computer software for
external use as incurred prior to the establishment of technological feasibility. The Company has determined that
technological feasibility for its software products is reached after all high-risk development issues have been resolved
through coding and testing. Costs incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility and prior to the
general release of the products are capitalized. For the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, software costs that
were eligible for capitalization have been immaterial, and as a result, no costs have been capitalized.

**_Capitalized Internal-Use Software_**

The Company capitalizes software development costs in accordance with ASC Topic 350-40, “Internal-Use
Software.” The Company capitalizes costs for software to be used internally when entering the application
development stage. This occurs when the preliminary project stage is complete, management authorizes and commits
to funding the project, and it is feasible that the project will be completed, and the software will perform the intended
function. The Company ceases to capitalize costs related to a software project when it enters the post-implementation
and operation stage. If different determinations are made with respect to the state of development of a software project,
then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ materially.

Costs capitalized during the application development stage consist of payroll and related costs for employees who are
directly associated with, and who devote time directly to, a project to develop software for internal use. The Company
also capitalizes the direct costs of materials and services, which generally includes outside contractors, and interest.
The Company does not capitalize any general and administrative or overhead costs or costs incurred during the
application development stage related to training or data conversion costs. Costs related to upgrades and enhancements
to internal-use software, if those upgrades and enhancements result in additional functionality, are capitalized. If
upgrades and enhancements do not result in additional functionality, those costs are expensed as incurred. If different
determinations are made with respect to whether upgrades or enhancements to software projects would result in


-----

additional functionality, then the amount capitalized and the amount charged to expense for that project could differ
materially.

The Company amortizes capitalized costs with respect to development projects for internal-use software when the
software is ready for use. The capitalized software development costs are generally amortized using the straight-line
method over a 3-year period. In determining and reassessing the estimated useful life over which the cost incurred for
the software should be amortized, the Company considers the effects of obsolescence, technology, competition and
other economic factors.

As of December 31, 2023 and 2022 capitalized software development costs were $7.0 million and $7.9 million,
respectively. Additions, relating to capitalized software development costs, incurred during the years ended December
31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were $0.6 million and $5.1 million, respectively.

**_Leases_**

The Company determines if an arrangement contains a lease at inception and does not separate lease and non-lease
components of an arrangement determined to contain a lease. Operating leases are included in right-of-use (“ROU”)
assets, current operating lease liabilities and operating lease liabilities, net of current portion, on the Company’s
consolidated balance sheet.

Operating leases with a duration of 12 months or less are excluded from ROU assets and operating lease liabilities
and related expenses are recorded as incurred.

ROU assets represent the Company’s right to use an underlying asset for the lease term and the corresponding lease
liabilities represent its obligation to make lease payments arising from the lease. Lease ROU assets and lease liabilities
are recognized based on the present value of the future minimum lease payments over the lease term at the lease
commencement date. The lease ROU asset includes any initial direct costs incurred and is reduced for tenant
incentives. As the Company’s operating leases do not provide an implicit rate, the net present value of future minimum
lease payments is determined using the Company’s incremental borrowing rate. To determine the estimated
incremental borrowing rate, the Company performs a synthetic credit rating analysis and uses publicly available credit
ratings for peer companies based upon the determined synthetic credit rating analysis. The Company estimates the
incremental borrowing rate using yields for maturities that are in line with the duration of the lease payments.

The Company evaluates the recoverability of the ROU assets for possible impairment in accordance with the longlived assets policy above.

Lease expense for minimum lease payments for operating leases is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease
term. Improvement reimbursements from landlords are amortized through ROU assets on a straight-line basis as a
reduction to rent expense over the terms of the corresponding leases.

**_Asset Retirement Obligations_**

The Company accounts for asset retirement obligations in accordance with ASC Topic 410, “Asset Retirement and
Environmental Obligations”, which applies to certain obligations associated with “leasehold improvements” within
leased office facilities. ASC Topic 410 requires that a liability be initially recognized for the estimated fair value of
the obligation when it is incurred. The associated asset retirement cost is capitalized as part of the carrying amount of
the long-lived asset and depreciated over the remaining life of the underlying asset and the associated liability is
accreted to the estimated fair value of the obligation at the settlement date through periodic accretion charges which
are generally recorded within “General and administrative” expense in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of
Operations and Comprehensive Income. When the obligation is settled, any difference between the final cost and the
recorded amount is recognized as income or loss on settlement in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Income.

**_Foreign Currency Translation and Transaction Accounting_**


-----

Certain transactions of the Company and its subsidiaries are denominated in currencies other than their functional
currency. Foreign currency exchange gain (loss) generated from the settlement and remeasurement of these
transactions are recognized in earnings and presented within “Other income (expense), net” in the Company’s
Consolidated Statements of Operations. Net foreign currency transaction and remeasurement gain (loss) reflected in
“Other income (expenses), net” for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, were $(25.1) million and $11.6
million, respectively.

Assets and liabilities of foreign subsidiaries whose functional currency is not the U.S. dollar are translated into U.S.
dollars at current exchange rates, while revenues, costs and expenses are translated at average exchange rates during
each reporting period. The resulting currency translation gain (loss) are included in “Accumulated other
comprehensive income (loss)” in the Company’s consolidated balance sheets.

**_Comprehensive Income (Loss)_**

Comprehensive income (loss) represents the change in equity during a period from transactions and other events and
circumstances from nonowner sources. Comprehensive income (loss) consists of the net income (loss), foreign
currency translation gain (loss), unrealized gain (loss) on derivative contracts, net, and is reported within the
Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss).

**_Other Income (Expense)_**

Other income (expense) includes interest income, gains and losses on long-lived asset disposals, gains and losses on
derivative instruments not designated for hedging, gains on investments, losses on early retirement of debt, and
realized and unrealized foreign currency transaction gains and losses.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

The Company is exposed to market risk in the ordinary course of business. Market risk represents the risk of loss that
may impact financial position due to adverse changes in financial market prices and rates. Market risk exposure is
primarily a result of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, customer concentrations and interest rates. The
Company does not hold or issue financial instruments for trading purposes.

**Foreign Currency Exchange Risk**

Approximately 15% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023 were earned in non-U.S. dollar denominated
currencies, principally the Euro, British pound, and Australian Dollar. Expenses are generally denominated in the
currencies in which operations are located, primarily the U.S. dollar, and to a lesser extent the British pound, Euro,
and Indian Rupee. The consolidated results of operations and cash flows are, therefore, subject to fluctuations due to
changes in foreign currency exchange rates and may be adversely affected in the future due to changes in foreign
exchange rates. The Company may use derivative contracts, including currency swaps, in an effort to mitigate the risk
of foreign currency fluctuations relative to the U.S. dollar. In addition, natural hedging exists in several currencies
where the Company has revenue and expenses including the four largest exposure currencies: Euro, British pound,
Australian dollar and Japanese yen. However, these hedges do not completely eliminate foreign exchange risk and


-----

therefore changes in foreign currency exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and foreign currencies could have a
material impact on cash flows and net income (loss).

**Interest Rate Risk**

The Company has unrestricted cash of $239.0 million and $157.8 million at December 31, 2023 and December 31,
2022, respectively. Cash balances are held at highly rated banks within highly liquid bank deposits and money market
funds. The Company does not believe cash deposits have significant risk of default or illiquidity. While the Company
believes cash equivalents do not contain excessive risk, the Company cannot provide absolute assurance that in the
future cash will not be subject to adverse changes in the credit profile of those banks. In addition, the Company
maintains significant amounts of cash at one or more financial institutions that are in excess of federally insured limits.
The Company cannot be assured that it will not experience losses on these deposits.

The Company is exposed to interest rate risk related to variable-rate debt it has issued or borrowed, including debt
under the Existing First Lien Term Loans and the Existing First Lien Revolving Credit Facility. The Company issues
long-term debt in either U.S. dollars or foreign currencies based on market conditions at the time of financing. The
Company may use interest rate swaps to modify the market risk exposures in connection with the debt to obtain a
fixed interest rate. The swap transactions generally involve the exchange of floating for fixed interest payments.
However, the Company may choose not to swap floating for fixed interest payments or may terminate a previously
executed swap if the Company believes a larger proportion of variable-rate debt would be beneficial.

**Client Relationship with IBM**

A significant portion of revenue is derived from a partnership agreement with IBM, whereby IBM licenses software
products on an OEM basis and pays a royalty based on IBM’s recorded license, maintenance and subscription revenue.
IBM is responsible for sales and marketing (i.e. “go-to-market”) of IBM-branded products. The Company derives a
significant portion of revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM and a termination of this partnership
would have a material adverse effect on the Company’s business, financial condition, results of operations and
prospects.

**Inflation**

The Company recognizes that inflationary pressures may have an adverse effect on the Company through higher labor
and other operating costs. The Company tries to minimize these impacts through effective control of operating
expenses and productivity improvements, as well as price increases to customers. The Company does not believe that
inflation has had a material effect on the business, financial condition or results of operations. Nonetheless, if costs
were to become subject to significant inflationary pressures, the Company may not be able to fully offset such higher
costs. The inability or failure to do so could harm the business, financial condition and results of operations.

**Overview**

The AMC business includes historically a product group of Micro Focus and, beginning February 1, 2023, the OT
Connectivity business, a product group of OpenText. OpenText acquired all of the issued and to be issued share capital
of Micro Focus on January 31, 2023 as part of the MF Acquisition. For the period starting January 1, 2022 to the date
of the MF Acquisition, reference to the “Parent” is to Micro Focus. For the period after the MF Acquisition starting
on February 1, 2023, reference to the “Parent” is to OpenText. The audited combined carveout financial statements
included elsewhere in this offering memorandum have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis. The periods presented
were prepared on a standalone basis and have been derived from the accounting records of Micro Focus prior to the
MF Acquisition and OpenText following the MF Acquisition. The audited combined carveout financial statements
herein have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. Prior to the date of the MF Acquisition, the accounting records
and financial information of Micro Focus were prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting
Standards, as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (“IFRS”) and had a different fiscal year end. In
preparing the audited combined carveout financial statements, the AMC business presents a fiscal period ended
December 31 and has converted any financial information to GAAP. Please see Note 1, Organization and Basis of
_Presentation to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum_
for more information on how the audited combined carveout financial statements have been prepared.

The AMC business provides market leading mainframe modernization and connectivity software to more than 10,000
customers, enabling them to run mission-critical business applications in hybrid cloud environments. As of December
31, 2023, the AMC business employed a total of 769 individuals. Of the total 769 individuals the AMC business
employed as of December 31, 2023, 334 or 43.4% were in the Americas, consisting of countries in North, Central
and South America, 391 or 50.9% were in EMEA, consisting of countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa,
and 44 or 5.7% were in Asia Pacific, primarily consisting of Japan, Australia, China, Korea, the Philippines,
Singapore, India and New Zealand. Currently, the AMC business has employees in 29 countries, enabling strong
access to multiple talent pools while ensuring reach and proximity to customers. Please see “—Results of Operations”
below for the definitions of geographic regions.

**_Fiscal 2023 Summary:_**

  - Total revenue was $507.7 million, up 13.2% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. The addition
of OT Connectivity, as of February 1, 2023, contributed $37.9 million of revenue.

  - Total annual recurring revenue, which consists of customer support revenue, was $335.0 million, up 11.2%
compared to the year ended December 31, 2022.

  - Gross margin was 90.7% compared to 93.1% in the year ended December 31, 2022, down 2.4%.


-----

  - Net income was $199.1 million compared to $219.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, down
9.4%.

  - Operating cash flow was $209.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to $227.5 million
in the year ended December 31, 2022, down 7.9%.

  - Period to period comparability was impacted by the addition of OT Connectivity to the AMC business, as
of February 1, 2023.

  - On November 28, 2023, OpenText entered into the Acquisition Agreement with Rocket, involving the
purchase and sale of the AMC business. Under the Acquisition Agreement, OpenText will receive
approximately $2.275 billion in cash at closing.

**_Impacts of Geopolitical Conflicts and Diplomatic Tensions_**

The AMC business continues to monitor the geopolitical conflicts and diplomatic tensions around the world, including
the Israel-Hamas war. The AMC business continues to operate its Israeli-based business and support the employees
of the AMC business in the region. While operations affected by these locations are not material and there is not an
expectation that these geopolitical conflicts will have a material adverse effect on the overall business, results of
operations or financial condition, it is not possible to predict the broader consequences of these conflicts, including
adverse effects on the global economy, on the AMC business and operations as well as those of the AMC business’s
customers, partners and third-party service providers.

**Critical Accounting Estimates**

The AMC business has identified the following accounting estimates as critical to its business operations and the
understanding of the AMC business’s results of operations. The preparation of the audited combined carveout financial
statements requires The AMC business to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets
and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the audited combined carveout financial
statements, and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. While The AMC business
does not believe that a change in these estimates is reasonably likely, there can be no assurance that actual results will
not differ from these estimates.

The AMC business’s accounting policies are described in Note 1, Organization and Basis of Presentation and Note 2,
_Summary of Significant Accounting Policies to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere_
in this offering memorandum. The following discussion should be read in conjunction with _Note 2, Summary of_
_Significant Accounting Policies, as it presents uncertainties involved in applying the accounting policies and provides_
insight into the quality of the management of the AMC business’s estimates and variability in the amounts recorded
for these critical accounting estimates. The AMC business’s critical accounting estimates include the following:

**_Revenue Recognition_**

In accordance with ASC 606, the AMC business accounts for a customer contract when the AMC business obtains
written approval, the contract is committed, the rights of the parties, including the payment terms, are identified, the
contract has commercial substance and consideration is probable of collection. Revenue is recognized when, or as,
control of a promised product or service is transferred to the AMC business’s customers in an amount that reflects the
consideration the AMC business expects to be entitled to in exchange for products and services (at its transaction
price). Estimates of variable consideration and the determination of whether to include estimated amounts in the
transaction price are based on readily available information, which may include historical, current and forecasted
information, taking into consideration the type of customer, the type of transaction and specific facts and
circumstances of each arrangement. The AMC business reports revenue net of any revenue-based taxes assessed by
governmental authorities that are imposed on and concurrent with specific revenue producing transactions. The AMC
business has three revenue streams: customer support, licenses and professional services.


-----

**_Goodwill_**

Impairment testing for goodwill is performed annually or more frequently if impairment indicators are present. To
determine if goodwill is potentially impaired, the AMC business has the option to perform a qualitative assessment.
However, the AMC business may elect to bypass the qualitative assessment and perform a quantitative impairment
test even if no indications of a potential impairment exist.

The process of estimating the fair value of goodwill is subjective and requires the AMC business to make estimates
that may significantly impact the outcome of the analysis. Under the qualitative assessment, the AMC business
considers several qualitative factors, including the business enterprise value of the reporting unit and the excess of fair
value over carrying value from this test, macroeconomic conditions, industry and market considerations, the recent
and projected financial performance of the reporting unit, cost factors, as well as other factors.

The AMC business has concluded that there is one reporting unit and assigned the entire balance of goodwill to this
reporting unit. On December 31, 2023, and 2022, the AMC business performed its qualitative impairment test for
goodwill which indicated that the fair value for the reporting unit exceeded the carrying value, and therefore did not
result in a goodwill impairment. Refer to the Goodwill discussion in _Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting_
_Policies to the audited combined carveout financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for_
additional information.

**_Corporate Allocations_**

The audited combined carveout financial statements have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis and include an
allocated share of costs related to Parent corporate functions for certain services provided to the AMC business.
Expenses are allocated to the AMC business based on utilization or other metrics deemed reasonable and appropriate
by the management of the AMC business (e.g., revenue or headcount). As such, the audited combined carveout
financial statements may not include all of the actual expenses that would have been incurred and may not reflect the
AMC business’s results of operations, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows, had it been a
standalone company during the periods presented. Actual costs that would have been incurred if the AMC business
had been a standalone company would depend on multiple factors, including organization structure and various other
strategic decisions. Refer to Note 1, Organization and Basis of Presentation to the audited combined carveout financial
statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for more information.

**_Income Taxes_**

Income tax benefit (provision) represents the income tax benefit or expense associated with the AMC business’s
operations based on the tax laws of the jurisdictions in which the AMC business operates. Foreign jurisdictions in
which the AMC business operates have different statutory tax rates. The AMC business did not operate as a standalone
entity in the past and, accordingly, tax losses, receivables and other deferred tax assets included in the audited
combined carveout financial statements on a separate return basis may not be available upon separation of the AMC
business from Parent.

Deferred income taxes are provided for temporary differences in the bases between financial reporting and income
tax assets and liabilities. Deferred income taxes are recalculated annually at tax rates in effect for the years in which
those tax assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. AMC records valuation allowances to reduce the
deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized. Separately, tax positions taken or expected
to be taken in a tax return are measured at the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50 percent likely of
being realized upon ultimate settlement.

The AMC business’s effective tax rate fluctuates from period to period due to changes in the mix of income and losses
in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences, certain one-time items and changes in tax
contingencies. Refer to _Note 10, Income Taxes in the audited combined carveout financial statements included_
elsewhere in this offering memorandum for further discussion.

projects during 2023.

Total operating expenses increased by $60.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, relative to the year ended
December 31, 2022, which is comprised of additional research and development, sales and marketing, and general
and administrative allocated shared corporate costs of $29.0 million, the AMC business’s direct expenses of $26.0

**_Revenues, Cost of Revenues and Gross Margin by Product Type_**

**_Customer Support_**

Customer support revenues consist of revenues from customer support and maintenance agreements. These
agreements allow customers to receive technical support, enhancements and upgrades to new versions of software
products when available. Customer support revenues are generated from support and maintenance relating to current
year sales of software products and from the renewal of existing maintenance agreements for software licenses sold
in prior periods. Therefore, changes in customer support revenues do not always correlate directly to the changes in
license revenues from period to period. The terms of support and maintenance agreements are typically twelve months,
and are renewable, generally on an annual basis, at the option of the customer. The management of the AMC business
reviews customer support renewal rates on a quarterly basis, and use these rates as a method of monitoring customer
service performance. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the customer support renewal rate for the AMC business
was approximately 91.8%, compared to approximately 90.8% for the year ended December 31, 2022. For OT
Connectivity, customer support renewal rate was 95.8% for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to the 94.5%
for the year ended December 31, 2022.

Cost of customer support revenues is comprised primarily of technical support personnel and related costs, as well as
contract labor and third-party consulting costs.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

The AMC business is primarily exposed to market risks associated with fluctuations in interest rates and foreign
currency exchange rates.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

The AMC business’s exposure to interest rate risk is minimal as it does not hold any financial instruments with
significant interest rate sensitivity. The management of the AMC business regularly assesses the nature and extent of
the AMC business’s exposure to interest rate risks.

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

**_Foreign currency transaction risk_**

The AMC business transacts in various foreign currencies. Foreign currency exposures typically arise from
transactions that are expected to be cash settled in the near term and are transacted in non-functional currency.
Management expects that the AMC business will continue to realize gains or losses with respect to the AMC business’s
foreign currency exposures. The ultimate realized gain or loss with respect to foreign currency exposures will generally
depend on the size and type of cross-currency transactions that the AMC business enters into, the currency exchange
rates associated with these exposures and changes in those rates.

The AMC business has not entered into derivatives or hedging transactions as exposure to foreign currency exchange
rates has not been material to the audited combined carveout financial statements.


-----

**_Foreign currency translation risk_**

The AMC business’s reporting currency is the U.S. dollar. Fluctuations in foreign currencies impact the amount of
total assets and liabilities that the AMC business reports for foreign subsidiaries upon the translation of these amounts
into U.S. dollars.
