In 2018, the Company entered into a credit facility with a syndicate of lenders that was comprised of (i) a first lien
term loan in an aggregate principal amount of $1,300.0 million (the “First Lien Term Loan”), (ii) the conversion of
$825.0 million in borrowings under the First Lien Term Loan into borrowings of $470.0 million (the “Dollar Term
Loan”) and 300.0 million Euro (the “Euro Term Loan”) via a syndicate of lenders, each with a maturity date of
November 2025.

On October 5, 2023, the Company amended its credit agreements to extend the maturity date of its First Lien debt
from November 2025 to November 2028, decrease the combined USD term loan under the First Lien Term Loan
and the Dollar Term Loan to an aggregate principal of approximately $1,407.5 million (the “New Dollar Term
Loan), and increase the Euro term loan from €300.0 to €575.0 million (the “New Euro Term Loan” and, together
with the New Dollar Term Loan, the “Existing First Lien Term Loan”). The Company paid $30.1 million of original
issue discount which was recorded net within Long-term debt and is being amortized over the term of the agreement
to interest expense. The Company paid $10.0 million of third-party fees, of which $0.8 million, related to new
lenders in the syndication, were recorded net within Long-term debt and are being amortized over the term of the
agreement to interest expense and $9.2 million, related to existing lenders in the syndication, were expensed and
recorded within general and administrative in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The Company expensed
$2.6 million for loss of extinguishment of debt related to lenders exiting the syndication and recorded within other
(expense) income, net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.

Under the terms of the New Dollar Term Loan, the principal amount is paid in quarterly installments equal to 1.0%
of the original principal amount per annum until the final maturity date, and monthly floating interest rate payments
are made based on the one-month Term SOFR rate, plus a margin of 4.75%. Under the terms of the New Euro Term
Loan, the Company will make monthly floating interest rate payments based on the one-month EURIBOR rate (with
a minimum of 0.00%) plus a margin of 4.75%. The Company has an option to adjust the Term SOFR and
EURIBOR interest periods from the one-month rate to another period under the agreement. The remaining principal
payment, after installment payments, is due upon maturity.

**11.** **Leases**

The Company is party to various leases for property, office space, equipment, and automobiles. The Company
determines if an arrangement contains a lease at inception or upon modification of a contract and classifies each
lease as either an operating or finance lease. The Company only reassesses lease classification subsequent to the
commencement date if the contract is modified. Finance and operating lease assets represent the Company’s right to
use an underlying asset as lessee for the lease term, and lease obligations represent the Company’s obligation to


-----

make lease payments arising from the lease. These assets and obligations are recognized at the lease commencement
date based on the present value of lease payments, net of incentives, over the lease term. Generally, the Company's
lease contracts do not provide a readily determinable implicit rate and, therefore, the Company uses its estimated
incremental borrowing rate as of the lease commencement date in determining the present value of lease payments.
The lease asset also reflects any lease payments made, initial direct costs incurred, and lease incentives received
prior to commencement date. The Company’s lease terms include periods under options to extend or terminate the
lease when it is reasonably certain that those options will be exercised.

Certain lease agreements contain variable payments, which are expensed as incurred and not included in the lease
assets and liabilities. These variable payments include insurance, taxes, payments tied to a consumer price index or
other such indices, and payments for maintenance and utilities. For all leases, the Company does not separate lease
components and non-lease components. Leases with an initial expected term of 12 months or less are not recorded in
the Consolidated Balance Sheets and the related lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease
term. Included in the Consolidated Balance Sheet at December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were the following

**Stock Options**

On June 21, 2019, the board of directors of BCPE Rover Holdings, Inc. (“BCPE Holdings”) ratified and approved
the adoption of the 2018 Stock Option Plan (the “Option Plan”), which authorizes BCPE Holdings to grant awards
to members of the board, officers and employees of the Company in BCPE Holdings, which is the indirect parent of
the Company. The Option Plan was adopted to incentive grant recipients to promote the long-term growth and
profitability of the Company and its affiliates. In accordance with the Option Plan, BCPE Holdings also authorized
550,000 shares of the Class B Common Stock of BCPE Holdings (“Class B Stock”) to be granted in the form of
nonqualified stock options. Stock compensation expense was $1.6 million, $2.8 million and $1.6 million for the
years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. The number of options granted to purchase Class B
Stock were 39,737 and 95,026 for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, respectively.

Options granted under the Option Plan are be exercisable only to the extent that they are vested. Option grants are
divided into two vesting tranches: “Time-Vesting Options” and “Performance-Vesting Options,” with a 50%
allocation to each tranche. Time-Vesting Options vest over a five-year period following the vesting start date (which
is typically the grant date). Twenty percent of the Time-Vesting Options will vest on each anniversary of the grant
date until all Time-Vested Options are fully-vested. All Time-Vesting options provide for accelerated vesting upon a
change of control and 100% will vest upon a change in control; however, an initial public offering will not
accelerate vesting. Performance-Vesting Options are subject to time and performance vesting and will only be fully
vested when they have met both time and performance vesting requirements. Performance-Vesting Options will time
vest in the same manner as Time-Vesting Options. Performance-Vesting Options will performance vest as follows:
50% vesting if funds associated with Bain Capital (“Sponsor”) Returns (as defined in the Option Plan) through the
measurement date are at least two times the initial Sponsor investment and 100% vesting if Sponsor Returns are at
least three times the initial Sponsor investment. An IPO may result in the accelerated vesting of PerformanceVesting Options.

As of December 31, 2023, the grant date fair value of the Time-Vesting and Performance-Vesting Options were
$11.8 million and $10.6 million, respectively. Remaining unrecognized compensation expense was $3.1 million for
the unvested Time Vesting Options as of December 31, 2023 and is expected to be recognized over the related
weighted average period of 2 years. The Company recorded compensation expense for the Time Vesting Options of
$1.6 million, $2.8 million and $1.6 million for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively,
which was included in general and administrative, cost of sales, research & development, and sales and marketing
expenses.

As of December 31, 2023, the Company has not deemed the achievement of the vesting criteria of the PerformanceVesting Options to be probable, and therefore there has been no compensation expense recorded for these
performance-based vesting awards to date. Total unrecognized compensation expense was $10.6 million for the
unvested Performance-Vesting Options as of December 31, 2023. The Company will reassess the probability of
achieving investor return targets at the end of each reporting period.

The Company is a private company and lacks certain company-specific historical and implied volatility information.
Therefore, it estimates its expected option volatility based on the historical volatility of a publicly traded group of
peer companies. The expected term of the Company’s equity interests is based on management’s estimate of time
until a potential liquidity event. The risk-free rate is determined by reference to the U.S. Treasury yield curve in
effect at the time of grant of the award for the time periods approximately equal to the expected term of the award.
Expected dividend yield is zero based on the fact that the Company does not expect to pay cash dividends.

**14.** **Concentration of Credit Risk and Significant Customers**

Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk include cash and cash
equivalents, restricted cash, billed and unbilled accounts receivable, and derivative instruments. At December 31,
2023 and December 31, 2022, the Company had cash and cash equivalent balances at certain financial institutions in
excess of federally insured limits. However, the Company maintains its cash and cash equivalents with accredited
financial institutions and does not believe that it is subject to unusual credit risk beyond the normal credit risk
associated with commercial banking relationships. Concentrated credit risk with respect to accounts receivable is
limited to large, creditworthy customers and partners. The Company has not experienced material credit losses
related to receivables from individual partners, customers or groups of customers in any specific industry or
geographic area. The Company manages credit risk with counterparties on derivative instruments by trading among
several counterparties and by trading with accredited financial institutions. The Company has no significant offbalance-sheet concentration of credit risk.

As of December 31, 2023, one strategic partner accounted for 40% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled
accounts receivable. As of December 31, 2022, one strategic partner accounted for 39% and one customer accounted
for 7% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled and accounts receivable. No other customer or partner
accounted for more than 3% of the Company’s combined billed and unbilled accounts receivable for any period
presented.

We derive a significant portion of our revenue from a long-term strategic partnership with IBM. For the fiscal years
ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, we generated 40%, 38% and 35%, respectively, of our total revenue
from this partnership. No other customer or partner accounted for more than 7% of our total revenue during these
periods.

**15.** **Derivatives**

**_Risk Management Objective of Using Derivatives_**

The Company enters into derivative instruments to manage risks related to its business operations and economic
conditions. Derivative financial instruments are used to manage exposures to interest rate and foreign exchange risk
in order to reduce the risk that the Company’s cash flows, earnings, and investment in foreign subsidiaries will be
adversely affected.


-----

On October 18, 2023, the Company settled and unwound its non-designated EUR cross-currency swap, resulting in
cash proceeds of $37.1 million. This gain has been recognized in Other income (expense) over the life of the
contract through mark to market. The Company recognized a gain of $2.4 million, $32.2 million and $2.5 million as
of December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively.

On October 31, 2023, the Company had its $200.0 million non-designated interest rate cap mature.

**_Cash Flow Hedges of Interest Rate Risk_**

The Company’s objectives in using interest rate derivatives are to add stability to interest expense and to manage its
exposure to interest rate movements. To accomplish this objective, the Company primarily uses interest rate
products such as swaps and caps as part of its interest rate risk management strategy. Interest rate swaps designated
as cash flow hedges involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty in exchange for the Company
making fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreements without exchange of the underlying notional amount.
Interest rate caps designated as cash flow hedges involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty if
interest rates rise above the strike rate on the contract in exchange for a premium. During 2022 and 2023, such
derivatives were used to hedge the variable cash flows associated with existing variable-rate debt. These contracts
have maturities of 23 months or less as of December 31, 2023.

For derivatives designated and that qualify as cash flow hedges of interest rate risk, the unrealized gain or loss on the
derivative is recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (“AOCI”) and subsequently reclassified into
interest expense in the same periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings. As of December 31,
2023, the net accumulated income deferred in AOCI on cash flow hedges before tax effect was $21.8 million, $18.6
million of which the Company expects will be reclassified to interest expense within the next 12 months.

**_Net Investment Hedges_**

The Company designated a fixed-to-fixed cross-currency swap agreement as a net investment hedge. The
Company’s risk management objective and strategy for the net investment hedge transaction is to protect a
designated monetary amount of the Company’s net investment in Rocket Software UK International, a GBPfunctional-currency consolidated subsidiary, against the risk of changes in the GBP-USD exchange rate. The
Company’s cross-currency swap involves the receipt of functional-currency-fixed-rate amounts from a counterparty
in exchange for the Company making foreign-currency fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreement. The
cross-currency swap also involves a final (at maturity) exchange of the functional-currency principal amount(s) for
the foreign-currency principal amount(s).

For derivatives designated as net investment hedges, the unrealized gain or loss is reported in Accumulated Other
Comprehensive Income as part of the cumulative translation adjustment. Amounts are reclassified out of
Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income into earnings when the hedged net investment is either sold or
substantially liquidated.


-----

**_Non-Designated Hedges_**

Derivatives not designated as hedges are not speculative and are used to manage the Company’s exposure to interest
rate and foreign exchange movements and other identified risks but do not meet the strict hedge accounting
requirements and/or the Company has not elected to apply hedge accounting. Changes in the fair value of
derivatives not designated in hedging relationships are recorded directly in Other income, net.

**16.** **Fair Value Measurements**

The guidance in ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, defines fair value, and establishes a fair value
hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the
highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1
measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The three levels of the fair
value hierarchy are described below:

Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.

Level 2 Inputs other than Level 1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as quoted prices for similar
assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be
corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.

Level 3 Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair
value of the assets and liabilities.

To the extent that valuation is based on models or inputs that are less observable or unobservable in the market, the
determination of fair value requires more judgment. Accordingly, the degree of judgment exercised by the Company
in determining fair value is greatest for instruments categorized in Level 3. A financial instrument’s level within the
fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.

Fair value is a market-based measure considered from the perspective of a market participant rather than an entityspecific measure. Therefore, even when market assumptions are not readily available, the Company’s own
assumptions are set to reflect those that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability at the
measurement date. The Company uses prices and inputs that are current as of the measurement date, including
during periods of market dislocation. In periods of market dislocation, the observability of prices and inputs may be
reduced for many instruments. This condition could cause an instrument to be reclassified from Level 1 to Level 2
or Level 2 to Level 3.

**17.** **Restructuring and Transformation Costs**

In December 2023, the Company announced the decision to exit its operations in China as a broader initiative to colocate many of the application modernization products at the Company’s development centers located in Vilnius,

The cost of the China exit plan is estimated to be $16.0 million to $18.0 million and consists primarily of employeerelated costs. The Company incurred $7.3 million of expense related to the program in the fourth quarter of 2023,

plan is expected to be complete in the first half of 2025.

_Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Combined Carveout Financial Statements_

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the combined carveout financial
statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an
auditors’ report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not
absolute assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS
will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material
misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve

###### Note 1. Organization and Basis of Presentation

_Organization_

The AMC Business (the “Business”), of Open Text Corporation (“OpenText”) includes Application Modernization & Connectivity
(“AMC”), historically a product group of Micro Focus International Limited, formerly known as Micro Focus International PLC,
(“Micro Focus”) and, beginning February 1, 2023, the OpenText Connectivity business (“OT Connectivity”), a product group of
OpenText. OpenText acquired all of the issued and to be issued share capital of Micro Focus on January 31, 2023 (“the Acquisition”).
The contribution of OT Connectivity is reflected as a transfer in of the OT Connectivity business in the Combined Carveout Statements
of Cash Flows, which represents OT Connectivity's net assets as of the Acquisition date, which is mainly comprised of goodwill and net
working capital, including accounts receivable and deferred revenues, and deferred tax assets. For the periods starting January 1, 2022
to the date of the Acquisition, reference to the “Parent” in these Combined Carveout Financial Statements is to Micro Focus. For the
period after the Acquisition starting on February 1, 2023, reference to the “Parent” in these Combined Carveout Financial Statements is
to Open Text.

The Business provides market leading mainframe modernization and connectivity software and its solutions are categorized in the
following areas: MF Common Business Oriented Language (“COBOL”), Host Connectivity, MF Enterprise Suite, Mainframe
Application Development Life Cycle Management (“ADLM”) and Common Object Request Broker Architecture (“CORBA”). The MF
COBOL product portfolio enables customers to develop, maintain, and deploy applications using COBOL across different platforms.
Host Connectivity, which is the portfolio containing OT Connectivity includes products for enterprises to manage host access across
desktop, web and mobile devices, manage mainframe access with enhanced security and integrate mainframe and host systems. MF
Enterprise Suite is a mainframe application which helps enterprises move mainframe workloads to the cloud, therefore, reducing costs
and increasing agility. Mainframe ADLM is comprised of products that offer enhanced mainframe applications which help shorten app
delivery cycles, including faster development and deployment, strengthen security via multifactor authentication and data encryption,
and optimize user interface experiences to boost productivity. The CORBA product facilitates distributed computing by providing a
standard process for software components to request services and exchange data in a networked environment.
On November 28, 2023, OpenText entered into a definitive agreement with Rocket Software, Inc. (“Rocket”), a Bain Capital portfolio
company, involving the purchase and sale of the Business (the “Transaction”). Under the Transaction, OpenText will receive
approximately $2.275 billion in cash at closing. Upon completion of the Transaction, the Business will be transferred by OpenText to a
newly formed wholly owned subsidiary of Rocket.

_Basis of Presentation_

The Combined Carveout Financial Statements prior to the date of the Acquisition represent the financial information of AMC’s portion
of the Business. Beginning February 1, 2023, the Combined Carveout Financial Statements represent the financial information
combining AMC’s portion and OT Connectivity’s portion of the Business, which is the date on which both were under common control
of OpenText.

The Combined Carveout Financial Statements have been prepared on a “carve-out” basis. The periods presented were prepared on a
standalone basis and have been derived from the accounting records of Micro Focus prior to the Acquisition and OpenText following
the Acquisition. The Combined Carveout Financial Statements herein have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted
accounting principles (“U.S. GAAP”). Prior to the date of the Acquisition, the accounting records and financial information of Micro
Focus were prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standard (“IFRS”) and had a different fiscal year end. In
preparing the Combined Carveout Financial Statements, the Business has aligned to a fiscal period ended December 31 and have
converted any financial information to U.S. GAAP.


-----

The historical results of income, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows presented in the Combined Carveout Financial
Statements may not be indicative of what they would have been had the Business actually been an independent standalone entity, nor
are they necessarily indicative of the Business’ future results of income, comprehensive income, financial position and cash flows. It is
not practicable to estimate actual costs that would have been incurred had the Business been a separate, standalone company. Financial
information presented in the financial statements and notes herein is presented in thousands of U.S dollars, unless otherwise stated.

The Combined Carveout Financial Statements include all revenues and costs directly attributable to the Business and an allocation of
expenses related to certain support services received from the Parent, such as, human resources, legal, finance, central and shared
technology, and various other Parent corporate functions and overhead. These expenses have been attributed to the Business based on
direct usage or benefit where identifiable, with the remainder allocated using a reasonable methodology primarily on the basis of revenue
or headcount. Management considers these allocations to be a reasonable reflection of the utilization of services or the benefits received.

The Combined Carveout Financial Statements include assets and liabilities specifically attributable to the Business. Parent’s net
investment, included within Equity, represents the Parent’s investment in the Business including accumulated net earnings attributable
to Parent, the net effect of transactions with Parent and cost allocations from the Parent that were not historically allocated to the
Business.

All intercompany transactions and balances within the Business have been eliminated. Transactions with the Parent and the Business
are deemed to have been settled immediately through Net parent investment and are reflected in Equity as Net transfers to/from Parent.

Cash has not been assigned to the Business for any of the periods presented because those cash balances are not directly attributable to
the Business as a centralized approach was used by the Parent to manage cash and financing of its operations. These arrangements are
not reflective of the manner in which the Business would have financed its operations had it been a standalone company separate from
the Parent during the periods presented. Cash pooling, related interest, and intercompany arrangements are excluded from the asset and
liability balances in the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets. These amounts have instead been reported within Net parent investment,
as a component of Equity.

The Parent’s long-term debt and related interest expense have not been attributed to the Business for any of the periods presented because
the Parent’s borrowings are neither directly attributable to the Business nor is the Business the legal obligor of such borrowings.

The Income tax provisions in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income have been calculated as if the Business filed a separate tax
return and was operating as a standalone company. Therefore, tax expense and items of current and deferred taxes may not be reflective
of the Business’s actual tax balances.

The Business operates as one reportable segment based upon the information used by the chief operating decision maker (“CODM”) in
evaluating the performance of the Business and allocating resources and capital.


-----

**_Principles of Combination_**

The accompanying Combined Carveout Financial Statements include the accounts of the Business on a combined basis. The Business
also includes subsidiaries over which a direct or indirect legal or effective control exists and for which the Business is deemed to direct
the significant activities and has the obligation to absorb the losses or benefits of the entities. The Business does not constitute a solely
dedicated group of legal entities.

**_Use of estimates_**

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires the Business to make certain estimates, judgments and
assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements. These estimates, judgments and
assumptions are evaluated on an ongoing basis. Estimates are based on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are
believed to be reasonable at that time, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and
liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from those estimates. In particular, key estimates,
judgments and assumptions include those related to: (i) revenue recognition, (ii) accounting for income taxes, (iii) accounting for
allowance for doubtful accounts, (iv) accounting for goodwill and testing for impairment, (v) useful lives for property and equipment
and intangible assets, and (vi) the allocation of shared corporate costs.

###### Note 2. Accounting Policies and Recent Accounting Pronouncements

**Accounting Policies**

**_Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Credit Losses_**

In accordance with ASC Topic 326, “Financial Instruments – Credit Losses” (Topic 326), the Business recognizes expected credit losses
for accounts receivable and contract assets based on lifetime expected losses. Loss allowances are recognized using a collective
assessment for accounts receivable, including contract assets, with similar risk characteristics based on historical credit loss experience,
adjusted for forward-looking factors specific to the debtors and economic environment. The Business continues to maintain an allowance
for 100% of all accounts deemed to be uncollectible.

Customer creditworthiness is evaluated prior to order fulfillment and based on evaluations; the Business adjusts the credit limit to the
respective customer. In addition to these evaluations, the Business conducts on-going credit evaluations of customers’ payment history
and current creditworthiness. To date, the actual losses have been within the Business’ expectations. No single customer accounted for
more than 10% of the accounts receivable balance as of December 31, 2023 and 2022.

**_Property and equipment_**

Property and equipment are stated at the lower of cost or net realizable value and shown net of depreciation which is computed on a
straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the related assets. Gains and losses on asset disposals are taken into income in the
year of disposition. Fully depreciated property and equipment are retired from the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets when they are
no longer in use. Please see the “Impairment of long-lived assets” section below for policy on property and equipment impairments. The
following represents the estimated useful lives of property and equipment as of December 31, 2023 and 2022:

Computer hardware 1 to 5 years
Computer software 3 to 7 years

**_Leases_**

The Business enters into operating leases for certain facilities for use in the ordinary course of business. Leases with an initial term of
12 months or less are not recorded on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets.


-----

In accordance with ASC Topic 842, “Leases” (Topic 842), the Business accounts for a contract as a lease when the Business has the
right to direct the use of the asset for a period of time while obtaining substantially all of the asset’s economic benefits. The Business
determines the initial classification and measurement of the right of use (ROU) assets and lease liabilities at the lease commencement
date and thereafter if modified.

ROU assets represent the right to control the underlying assets under lease, and the lease liability is the Business’ obligation to make
the lease payments related to the underlying assets under lease, over the contractual term. ROU assets and lease liabilities are recognized
on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets based on the present value of future minimum lease payments to be made over the lease
term. When available, the Business will use the rate implicit in the lease to discount lease payments to present value. However, real
estate leases generally do not provide a readily determinable implicit rate, therefore, the Business must estimate the incremental
borrowing rate to discount the lease payments. The Business estimates the incremental borrowing rate based on a collateralized basis
with similar terms and payments, in the economic environment where the leased asset is located.

The ROU asset equals the lease liability, adjusted for any initial direct costs, prepaid rent and lease incentives on initial recognition.
Fixed lease costs are included in the recognition of ROU assets and lease liabilities. Variable lease costs are not included in the
measurement of the lease liability. These variable lease payments are recognized in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income in
the period in which the obligation for those payments is incurred. Lease expense for minimum lease payments continues to be recognized
in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

The Business has not elected the practical expedient to combine lease and non-lease components in the determination of lease costs for
facility leases. The lease liability includes lease payments related to options to extend or renew the lease term only if it is reasonably
certain the Business will exercise those options. The leases typically do not contain any material residual value guarantees or restrictive
covenants.

**_Goodwill_**

Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of net tangible and intangible assets
acquired. The carrying amount of goodwill is periodically reviewed for impairment (at a minimum annually) and whenever events or
changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value of this asset may not be recoverable.

The Business performs a qualitative assessment to test the reporting unit’s goodwill for impairment. Based on the qualitative assessment,
if the Business determines that the fair value of the reporting unit is more likely than not (i.e., a likelihood of more than 50 percent) to
be less than its carrying amount, the quantitative assessment of the impairment test is performed. In the quantitative assessment, the
Business compares the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value. If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying
value, goodwill is not considered impaired and the Business is not required to perform further testing. If the carrying value of the net
assets of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, then an impairment loss equal to the difference, but not exceeding the total carrying
value of goodwill allocated to the reporting unit, would be recorded.

The Business has concluded that there is one reporting unit and assigned the entire balance of goodwill to this reporting unit. The annual
impairment analysis of goodwill was performed as of December 31, 2023 and 2022. The qualitative assessment indicated that there were
no indications of impairment and therefore there was no impairment of goodwill required to be recorded for the years ended December
31, 2023 or 2022.

**_Acquired intangibles_**

Acquired intangibles consist of acquired technology and customer relationships, inclusive of tradenames associated with various
acquisitions. Acquired technology is initially recorded at fair value based on the present value of the estimated net future incomeproducing capabilities of software products acquired in acquisitions. The Business amortizes acquired technology over its estimated
useful life on a straight-line basis.

Customer relationships and tradenames represent relationships that the Business has with customers of the acquired companies and are
either based upon contractual or legal rights or are considered separable; that is, capable of being separated from the acquired entity and


-----

being sold, transferred, licensed, rented or exchanged. These customer relationships and tradenames are initially recorded at their fair
value based on the present value of expected future cash flows. The Business amortizes technology, tradenames, and customer
relationship on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives.

Technology 4 to 10 years
Tradenames 10 years
Customer relationships 7 to 10 years

The Business continually evaluates the remaining estimated useful life of the intangible assets being amortized to determine whether
events and circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of amortization.

**_Impairment of long-lived assets_**

The Business accounts for the impairment and disposition of long-lived assets in accordance with ASC Topic 360, “Property, Plant, and
Equipment” (Topic 360). The Business tests long-lived assets or asset groups, such as property and equipment, ROU assets and definite
lived intangible assets, for recoverability when events or changes in circumstances indicate that their carrying amount may not be
recoverable. Circumstances which could trigger a review include but are not limited to: significant adverse changes in the business
climate or legal factors; current period cash flow or operating losses combined with a history of losses or a forecast of continuing losses
associated with the use of the asset; and a current expectation that the asset will more likely than not be sold or disposed of before the
end of its estimated useful life.

Recoverability is assessed based on comparing the carrying amount of the asset to the aggregate pre-tax undiscounted cash flows
expected to result from the use and eventual disposal of the asset or asset group. Impairment is recognized when the carrying amount is
not recoverable and exceeds the fair value of the asset or asset group. The impairment loss, if any, is measured as the amount by which
the carrying amount exceeds fair value, which for this purpose is based upon the discounted projected future cash flows of the asset or
asset group.

The Business has not recorded any impairment charges for long-lived assets during 2023 or 2022.

**_Revenue recognition_**

In accordance with ASC Topic 606, “Revenue from Contracts with Customers” (Topic 606), the Business accounts for a customer
contract when the Business obtains written approval, the contract is committed, the rights of the parties, including the payment terms,
are identified, the contract has commercial substance and consideration is probable of collection. Revenue is recognized when, or as,
control of a promised product or service is transferred to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Business expects to
be entitled to in exchange for products and services (at its transaction price). Estimates of variable consideration and the determination
of whether to include estimated amounts in the transaction price are based on readily available information, which may include historical,
current and forecasted information, taking into consideration the type of customer, the type of transaction and specific facts and
circumstances of each arrangement. The Business reports revenue net of any revenue-based taxes assessed by governmental authorities
that are imposed on and concurrent with specific revenue producing transactions.

The Business has three primary revenue streams: customer support, license, and professional service.

**_Customer support revenue_**

Customer support revenue is associated with perpetual and term license. As customer support is not critical to the customer’s ability to
derive benefit from its right to use software, customer support is considered as a distinct performance obligation when sold together in
a bundled arrangement along with the software.

Customer support consists primarily of technical support and the provision of unspecified updates and upgrades on a when-and-ifavailable basis. Customer support for perpetual licenses is renewable, generally on an annual basis, at the option of the customer.
Customer support for term licenses is renewable concurrently with such licenses for the same duration of time. Payments for customer


-----

support are generally made at the inception of the contract term or in installments over the term of the maintenance period. The customer
support team is ready to provide these maintenance services, as needed, to the customer during the contract term. As the elements of
customer support are delivered concurrently and have the same pattern of transfer, customer support is accounted for as a single
performance obligation. The customer benefits evenly throughout the contract period from the guarantee that the customer support
resources and personnel will be available to them, and that any unspecified upgrades or unspecified future products developed by the
Business will be made available. Revenue for customer support is recognized ratably over the contract period based on the start and end
dates of the maintenance term, in line with how the Business believes services are provided.

**_License revenue_**

License revenue can be broadly categorized as perpetual licenses and term licenses, all of which are deployed on the customer’s
premises.

**Perpetual licenses: The Business sells perpetual licenses which provide customers the right to use software for an indefinite period**
of time in exchange for a one-time license fee, which is generally paid at contract inception. Perpetual licenses provide a right to
use IP that is functional in nature and have significant stand-alone functionality. Accordingly, for perpetual licenses of functional
IP, revenue is recognized at the point-in-time when control has been transferred to the customer, which normally occurs once
software activation keys have been made available for download.

**Term licenses: The Business sells term licenses which provide customers the right to use software for a specified period in**
exchange for a fee, which may be paid at contract inception or paid in installments over the period of the contract. Like perpetual
licenses, term licenses include functional IP that have significant stand-alone functionality. Accordingly, for term licenses, revenue
is recognized at the point-in-time when the customer is able to use and benefit from the software, which is normally once software
activation keys have been made available for download at the commencement of the term.

**_Professional service revenue_**

Professional services, when offered along with software licenses, consist primarily of technical and training services. Technical services
may include installation, customization, implementation or consulting services. Training services may include access to online modules
or delivering a training package customized to the customer’s needs. At the customer’s discretion, the Business may offer one, all, or a
mix of these services. Payment for professional services is generally a fixed fee or is a fee based on time and materials. Professional
services can be arranged in the same contract as the software license or in a separate contract.

As professional services do not significantly change the functionality of the license and customers can benefit from the Business’
professional services on their own or together with other readily available resources, the Business considers professional services as
distinct within the context of the contract.

Professional service revenue is recognized over time so long as: (i) the customer simultaneously receives and consumes the benefits as
the Business performs them, (ii) performance creates or enhances an asset the customer controls as the Business performs, and (iii)
performance does not create an asset with alternative use and the Business has enforceable right to payment.

If all the above criteria are met, the Business uses an input-based measure of progress for recognizing professional service revenue. For
example, total labor hours incurred compared to total expected labor hours may be considered. As a practical expedient, when a customer
is invoiced at an amount that corresponds directly with the value to the customer of the Business’ performance to date, the Business will
recognize revenue at that amount.


-----

**_Material rights_**

To the extent that the Business grants a customer an option to acquire additional products or services in one of the arrangements, the
Business will account for the option as a distinct performance obligation in the contract only if the option provides a material right to
the customer that the customer would not receive without entering into the contract. For example, if a customer is given an option to
acquire additional goods or services in the future at a price that is significantly lower than the current price, this would be a material
right as it allows the customer to, in effect, pay in advance for the option to purchase future products or services. If a material right exists
in one of the contracts, then revenue allocated to the option is deferred and the Business would recognize revenue only when those future
products or services are transferred or when the option expires.

Based on history, contracts do not typically contain material rights and when they do, the material right is not significant to the Combined
Carveout Financial Statements.

**_Arrangements with multiple performance obligations_**

Contracts generally contain more than one of the products and services listed above. Determining whether goods and services are
considered distinct performance obligations that should be accounted for separately or as a single performance obligation may require
judgment, specifically when assessing whether both of the following two criteria are met:

    - the customer can benefit from the product or service either on its own or together with other resources that are readily
available to the customer; and

    - the Business’ promise to transfer the product or service to the customer is separately identifiable from other promises in the
contract.

If these criteria are not met, the Business determines an appropriate measure of progress based on the nature of the Business’ overall
promise for the single performance obligation. If these criteria are met, each product or service is separately accounted for as a distinct
performance obligation and the total transaction price is allocated to each performance obligation on a relative standalone selling price
(“SSP”) basis.

**_SSP_**

The SSP reflects the price that would be charged for a specific product or service if it were sold separately in similar circumstances and
to similar customers. In most cases, the SSP can be established based on observable data. The Business typically establishes a narrow
SSP range for the products and services and assess this range on a periodic basis or when material changes in facts and circumstances
warrant a review.

If the SSP is not directly observable, then the Business estimates the amount using either the expected cost plus a margin or residual
approach. Estimating SSP requires judgment that could impact the amount and timing of revenue recognized. SSP is a formal process
whereby management considers multiple factors including, but not limited to, geographic or regional specific factors, competitive
positioning, internal costs, profit objectives, and pricing practices.

**_Transaction Price Allocation_**

In bundled arrangements, where the Business has more than one distinct performance obligation, the Business must allocate the
transaction price to each performance obligation based on its relative SSP. However, in certain bundled arrangements, the SSP may not
always be directly observable. For instance, in bundled arrangements with license and customer support, the Business allocates the
transaction price between the license and customer support performance obligations using the residual approach because the Business
has determined that the SSP for licenses in these arrangements are highly variable. The Business uses the residual approach only for
license arrangements. When the SSP is observable but contractual pricing does not fall within the established SSP range, then an
adjustment is required, and the Business will allocate the transaction price between license and customer support based on the relative
SSP established for the respective performance obligations.


-----

When two or more contracts are entered into at or near the same time with the same customer, the Business evaluates the facts and
circumstances associated with the negotiation of those contracts. Where the contracts are negotiated as a package, the Business will
account for them as a single arrangement and allocate the consideration for the combined contracts among the performance obligations
accordingly.

**_Sales to resellers_**

The Business executes certain sales contracts through resellers, distributors and channel partners (collectively referred to as resellers).
Typically, the Business concludes that the resellers are customers of the Business in reseller agreements. The resellers have control over
the pricing, service and products prior to being transferred to the end customer. The Business also assess the creditworthiness of each
reseller and if they are newly formed, undercapitalized or in financial difficulty, the Business defers any revenues expected to emanate
from such reseller and recognize revenue only when cash is received, and all other revenue recognition criteria under ASC Topic 606
are met.

**_Rights of return and other incentives_**

The Business does not generally offer rights of return or any other incentives such as concessions, product rotation, or price protection
and, therefore, do not provide for or make estimates of rights of return and similar incentives.

Additionally, in some contracts, however, discounts may be offered to the customer for future software purchases and other additional
products or services. Such arrangements grant the customer an option to acquire additional products or services in the future at a discount
and therefore are evaluated under guidance related to “material rights” as discussed above.

**_Other policies_**

Payment terms and conditions vary by contract type, although terms generally include a requirement of payment within 30 to 60 days
of the invoice date. In certain arrangements, the Business will receive payment from a customer either before or after the performance
obligation to which the invoice relates has been satisfied. As a practical expedient, the Business does not account for significant financing
components if the period between when the Business transfers the promised good or service to the customer and when the customer
pays for the product or service will be one year or less. On that basis, contracts for license and maintenance typically do not contain a
significant financing component, however, in determining the transaction price the Business considers whether there is a need to adjust
the promised consideration for the effects of the time value of money if the timing of payments provides either the customer or the
Business with a significant benefit of financing.

The Business may modify contracts to offer customers additional products or services. The additional products and services will be
considered distinct from those products or services transferred to the customer before the modification and will be accounted for as a
separate contract. The Business evaluates whether the price for the additional products and services reflects the SSP adjusted as
appropriate for facts and circumstances applicable to that contract. In determining whether an adjustment is appropriate, the Business
evaluates whether the incremental consideration is consistent with the prices previously paid by the customer or similar customers.

Certain of the Business’ product support arrangements generally contain performance response time guarantees. The Business estimates
variable consideration on a contract basis because such arrangements are customer-specific. The Business uses an expected value
approach to estimate variable consideration based on historical business practices and current and future performance expectations to
determine the likelihood of incurring penalties.

**_Incremental Costs of Obtaining a Contract with a Customer_**

Incremental costs of obtaining a contract include only those costs that the Business incurs to obtain a contract that would not have
incurred if the contract had not been obtained, such as sales commissions. The Business has determined that certain of the commission
programs meet the requirements to be capitalized. Some commission programs are not subject to capitalization as the commission
expense is paid and recognized as the related revenue is recognized. In assessing costs to obtain a contract, the Business applies a
practical expedient that allows the Business to assess incremental costs on a portfolio of contracts with similar characteristics instead of
assessing the incremental costs on each individual contract. The Business does not expect the financial statement effects of applying
this practical expedient to the portfolio of contracts to be materially different than if the Business were to apply the standard to each
individual contract.

The Business pays commissions on the sale of new customer contracts as well as for renewals of existing contracts to the extent the
renewals generate incremental revenue. Commissions paid on renewal contracts are limited to the incremental new revenue and therefore
these payments are not commensurate with the commission paid on the original sale. The Business allocates commission costs to the
performance obligations in an arrangement consistent with the allocation of the transaction price. Commissions allocated to the license
performance obligation are expensed at the time the license revenue is recognized. Commissions allocated to professional service
performance obligations are expensed as incurred, as these contracts are generally for one year or less and the Business applies a practical
expedient to expense costs as incurred if the amortization period would have been one year or less. Commissions allocated to customer
support are capitalized and amortized consistent with the pattern of transfer to the customer of the services over the period expected to
benefit from the commission payment. As commissions paid on renewals are not commensurate with the original sale, the period of
benefit considers anticipated renewals. The benefit period is estimated to be approximately six years which is based on customer
contracts and the estimated life of technology.

Expenses for incremental costs associated with obtaining a contract are recorded within “Sales and marketing” expense in the Combined
Carveout Statements of Income.

Short-term capitalized costs to obtain a contract are included in “Prepaid expenses and other current assets”, while long-term capitalized
costs to obtain a contract are included in “Other assets” on the Combined Carveout Balance Sheets.

**_Research and development costs_**

Research and development costs internally incurred in creating computer software to be sold, licensed or otherwise marketed are
expensed as incurred unless they meet the criteria for deferral and amortization, as described in ASC Topic 985-20, “Costs of Software
to be Sold, Leased, or Marketed” (Topic 985-20). In accordance with Topic 985-20, costs related to research, design and development
of products are charged to expense as incurred and capitalized between the dates that the product is considered to be technologically
feasible and is considered to be ready for general release to customers. Based on historical experience, the dates relating to the
achievement of technological feasibility and general release of the product have substantially coincided. In addition, no significant costs
are incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility. As a result, the Business does not capitalize any research and
development costs relating to internally developed software to be sold, licensed or otherwise marketed.

|Performance Obligation|When Performance Obligation is Typically Satisfied|
|---|---|
|Customer support revenue: When and if available updates and upgrades and technical support License revenue: Software licenses (Perpetual and Term) Professional service revenue: Professional services|Ratable over the course of the service term (over time) When software activation keys have been made available for download (point in time) As the services are provided (over time)|

**_Advertising Expenses_**

Advertising costs, which include digital advertising, marketing programs and other promotional costs, are expensed as incurred.
Advertising expenses incurred for the years ended December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were $11,804 and $5,404, respectively
and recorded in Sales and Marketing expenses.

**_Income taxes_**

Income taxes as presented in the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements consist of current and deferred income taxes of
Parent in a manner that is systematic, rational and consistent with the principles of FASB ASC Topic 740: Income Taxes (“ASC 740”).
Accordingly, the Business’ income tax provision was prepared following the separate return method. The separate return method applies
ASC 740 to the stand-alone financial statements of each member of the consolidated group as if the group members were a separate
taxpayer and a stand-alone enterprise. The calculation of the Business’ income taxes on a separate return basis requires a considerable
amount of judgment and use of both estimates and allocations. As a result, actual transactions included in the consolidated financial
statements of Parent may not be included in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements. Similarly, the tax treatment of certain items
reflected in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements may not be reflected in the consolidated financial statements and tax returns
of Parent. Therefore, items such as net operating losses, credit carry-forwards and valuation allowances may exist in the stand-alone
financial statements that may or may not exist in Parent’s consolidated financial statements. As such, the income taxes of the Business
as presented in the Combined Carveout Financial Statements may not be indicative of the income taxes that the Business will generate
in the future.

Certain operations of the Business have historically been included in a consolidated tax return with other Parent entities. Current
obligations or receivables are deemed settled with Parent as a component of net parent investment for purposes of the Combined
Carveout Financial Statements. The effects of tax adjustments and settlements from taxing authorities are presented in the Combined
Carveout Financial Statements in the period to which they relate as if the Business were a separate filer.

Deferred income taxes are recognized using the asset and liability method on temporary differences arising at the balance sheet date
between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts. Deferred income taxes are recalculated annually at tax rates in
effect for the years in which those tax assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. The Business records valuation
allowances to reduce its deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.

Deferred tax assets are recognized in respect of all deductible temporary differences, carry-forwards of unused tax credits and unused
tax losses to the extent that it is more likely than not that taxable income will be available against which the temporary differences can
be utilized. The carrying amounts of deferred tax assets are subject to review at each balance sheet date and are reduced to the extent
that future taxable income are considered to be inadequate to allow all or part of any deferred tax asset to be utilized. Deferred tax assets
and liabilities are presented on a net basis for the same tax-paying component within the same tax jurisdiction.

The Business accounts for uncertain tax provisions by using a two-step approach. The first step is to evaluate the tax position for
recognition by determining if the weight of the available evidence indicates it is more likely than not, based solely on the technical
merits, that the position will be sustained on audit, including the resolution of related appeals or litigation processes, if any. The second
step is to measure the appropriate amount of the benefit to recognize. The amount of benefit to recognize is measured as the maximum
amount which is more likely than not to be realized. The tax position is derecognized when it is no longer more likely than not that the
position will be sustained on audit. On subsequent recognition and measurement, the maximum amount which is more likely than not
to be recognized at each reporting date will represent the Business’ best estimate, given the information available at the reporting date,
although the outcome of the tax position is not absolute or final. The Business recognizes both accrued interest and penalties related to
liabilities for income taxes within the “Provision for (recovery of) income taxes” line of the Combined Carveout Statements of Income
(see Note 10 “Income Taxes” for more details).


-----

**_Fair value of financial instruments_**

Carrying amounts of certain financial instruments, including accounts receivable trade and accounts payable and accrued liabilities
approximate the fair value due to the relatively short period of time between origination of the instruments and their expected realization.

**_Foreign currency_**

The Combined Carveout Financial Statements are presented in U.S. dollars. In general, the functional currency of entities is the local
currency. For each subsidiary, assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S dollars at the exchange
rates in effect at the balance sheet dates and revenues and expenses are translated at the average exchange rates prevailing during the
previous month of the transaction. The effect of foreign currency translation adjustments are recorded as a component of “Accumulated
other comprehensive income.” Transactional foreign currency gains (losses) included in the Combined Carveout Statements of Income
under the line item “Other income (expense), net” for the year ended December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 were $735 and
$(3,262), respectively.

**_Defined contribution plans_**

The Business has various defined contribution retirement plans around the world covering many of its employees. Under these plans,
employees can contribute a portion of their salary to the plan and the Business makes minimum non-elective contributions, discretionary
contributions, and matching contributions, depending on the terms of the specific plan. The majority of the plans are primarily located
in Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom and Germany. For the year ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, the Business made
contributions of $3,466 and $2,643, respectively, relating to the defined contribution retirement plans.

**_Share-based compensation_**

The Parent operated various equity-settled, share-based compensation plans during the periods and certain employees of the Business
participated in the Parent’s plans. Share-based compensation costs are measured in accordance with ASC Topic 718, “Compensation –
Stock Compensation” (Topic 718) on the grant date, based on the calculated fair value of the award. The Parent has elected to treat
awards with graded vesting as a single award when estimating fair value. Compensation cost is recognized on a straight-line basis over
the employee requisite service period, which in the Parent’s circumstance is the stated vesting period of the award, provided that total
compensation cost recognized at least equals the pro-rata value of the award that has vested. Compensation cost is initially based on the
estimated number of awards for which the requisite service is expected to be rendered. This estimate is adjusted in the period once actual
forfeitures are known.

balance substantially over the next three years thereafter. The Business applies the practical expedient and do not disclose performance

Refer to Note 2 “Accounting Policies and Recent Accounting Pronouncements” for additional information on the revenue policy.

The Business regularly evaluates the recoverability of its deferred tax assets and establishes a valuation allowance, if necessary, to
reduce the deferred tax assets to an amount that is more likely than not to be realized (a likelihood of more than 50 percent). Significant
judgment is required to determine whether a valuation allowance is necessary and the amount of such valuation allowance. The Business
continues to evaluate their taxable position and consider factors by taxing jurisdiction, including but not limited to factors such as
estimated taxable income, any historical experience of losses for tax purposes and the future growth of the Business. Based upon the
available evidence, management expects that the Business will be able to utilize the deferred tax assets (“DTAs”) based upon future
estimated taxable income.

###### Note 11. Segment Information

ASC Topic 280, “Segment Reporting” (Topic 280), establishes standards for reporting, by public business enterprises, information about
operating segments, products and services, geographic areas and major customers. The method of determining what information, under
Topic 280, to report is based on the way that an entity organizes operating segments for making operational decisions and how the
entity’s management and CODM assess an entity’s financial performance. The Business operates as one segment based upon the
information used by the CODM in evaluating the performance of the Business and allocating resources and capital.

###### Note 12. Commitments and Contingencies 

**_Legal_**

In the ordinary course of business, the Business may be involved in various claims and legal proceedings. Where it is determined, in
consultation with internal and external counsel, that a loss is probable and reasonably estimable in a given matter, the Business
establishes an accrual in accordance with Topic 450-20. As of the date of these Combined Carveout Financial Statements, the
aggregate of such accrued liabilities was not material to the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements and the Business does
not believe as of the date of these Combined Carveout Financial Statements that it is reasonably possible that a loss exceeding the
amounts already recognized will be incurred that would be material to the Business’ Combined Carveout Financial Statements.
